editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head:
ADVERTISEMENT.
blazon or coat of arms
div.p: FOR the better finding out what Drugs are Prohibited, they are marked thus *, being not brought directly from the Place of growth in Engli≈øh built Shipping, as in the New Book of Rates, p. 112 in the Act for Incouraging and Increa≈øing of Shipping and Navigation, is more largely expre≈ø≈øed. You will find tho≈øe that are Prohibited with this mark *, both in the Book and Catalogue.
THE TREASURY OF DRVGS UNLOCK'D.

OR A Full and True De≈øcription of all ≈øorts of Drugs, and Chymical Preparations, ≈øold by Drugi≈øts, Whereby you may know the place of their growth, and from whence they come, and how to di≈øtingui≈øh the Good from the Bad.

Very USEFUL for All Gentlemen, Merchants, Druggi≈øts, Doctors, Apothecaries, Chirurgeons, and their Apprentices. As al≈øo for all Travellers, Seamen, Cu≈øtomhou≈øe Officers, and all others that either Traffick in them, or make any u≈øe of them, or tho≈øe that Import or deliver any of 'em at the Water≈øide. Giving a true Accou ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of all tho≈øe that are Prohibited, and tho≈øe tha ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , whereby many needle≈øs Di≈øputes and „Äà‚óä„Äâ Suits may be prevented. The whole Work Alphabetically dige≈øted, with a compleat Catalogue of all Drugs, &c.

By Jo. Jacob Berl ‚Ä¢
of London, Merchant in Drugs.
London, Printed for John Harris at the Harrow again≈øt the Church in the Poultrey, and Tho‚ñ™ Howkins in George-Yard, in Lombard-≈øtret, 16 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Price Bound One Shilling.

div.head: Courteous and Benevolent READER.
div.p: CErtainly nothing can promote Trade more than for Men to learn and under≈øtand tho≈øe Commodities and Merchandizes; they do intend to Trade in; which gives me hopes that this Treati≈øe will be kindly accepted of, and that tho≈øe of the Trade of Druggi≈øt will be more Ingenuous than to hold that Popi≈øh Tenet, to keep the People in Ignorance. The Price Currant which is weekly publi≈øhed of Drugs, may prejudice, this cannot: For the more Men under≈øtand the goodne≈øs of a Commodity, the more value they will ≈øet upon it.

To avoid al≈øo tho≈øe dangers (of prohibited Goods) by which I have been (as it were) ≈øhipwracked, you will ea≈øily di≈øcern the places of growth, being mentioned almo≈øt to every Commodity, and thereby avoid tho≈øe Rocks and Perils by which I have fore-gone a good e≈øtate. Vale.

div.head: Adianthum Album, Adianthum Nigrum, Maidenhair.
div.p:
THe black groweth here in England, France, Germany, and Norway, and mo≈øt parts of Europe. It is to be cho≈øen, the Leaves very green, the ≈øtalks of a lively reddi≈øh, black and dry withal. There has of late been a very good ≈øort brought from Bergen in Norway; that
which comes from Bri≈øtol, and other parts in Wales, is generally very good al≈øo.

The white Maiden Hair is not ≈øo plentiful here, neither ≈øo much in u≈øe. It is brought from Italy, New-England, France, and other places; the Stalk of it is more of yellowi≈øh green, and the Leaves larger and thinner than the black.

div.head: Adeps Ca≈øtoris.
div.p: THe Fat of Ca≈øtor is taken from above the Cods of Ca≈øtor, of which the Dantzick and Poland ≈øort generally have, as it were, two Cods above the Ca≈øtor Cods, which are full of Fat.

div.head: Adeps Hominis.
div.p: THE Fat of Man is gathered from tho≈øe parts of Men, as Suet is made of other Creatures, and Hogs Lard from Hogs, of which the ≈øweete≈øt and cleane≈øt is to be preferred.

div.head: Adeps Ur≈øi.
div.p:
THE Fat of a Bear is of a very ≈øtinking ≈øtrong ≈ømell, very grea≈øie; 'tis for the mo≈øt part brought from Greenland
and other parts out of the North Countries.

div.head: Alumen Commune.
div.p: COmmon Allum is made here in England, and a great many other parts of Europe, it is in large great Lumps of a ≈øowri≈øh a≈øtringent ta≈øte, white, and clear.

div.head: Alumen Plumo≈øum.
div.p: IS in long ≈øhivers and long flakes, covered over with a ≈ømall white fine Du≈øt, not unlike to Feathers; it comes from Chio in the Straits, and likewi≈øe out of ≈øome parts of Germany: the be≈øt is in long flakes above an inch in length.

div.head: Alumen Roch.
div.p: IS an Allum which is roched, looks reddi≈øh and very clear as a Cry≈øtal, if broken, and tran≈øparent; it comes from Smyrna in Turky, and ≈øome places in Italy. It is al≈øo called Roman Allum.

div.head: Agaricus.
div.p: 'TIS an Excre≈øcence of a fungous Matter of a Tree, very white, and light, and cuts ea≈øily and ≈øhort: the be≈øt comes from Barbary; there is another ≈øort which comes from Helvetia, and other parts of Germany, viz. Norimberg; which is finer than that which comes from Ru≈ø≈øia, being in ≈ømall pieces, but very fine, white, and light: the Ru≈ø≈øia ≈øort is the cour≈øe≈øt of all, being ≈øometimes very cru≈øty, and interwoven with red Veins, as al≈øo flinty and ≈øandy, which is reckoned the wor≈øt.

div.head: * Alce Succotrina.
div.p: IS the fine≈øt of Aloes, therefore by ≈øome called Aloe Lucida; 'tis made in an I≈øland called Succatora near Moco in the Ea≈øt Indies; the fine≈øt is mo≈øt tran≈øparent, if broken, it turns to a fine yellowi≈øh Powder: 'tis brought to us from the Ea≈øt-Indies: the ≈ømalle≈øt, thinne≈øt, and lighte≈øt Bladders are to be preferred.

div.head: * Aloe Hepatica.
div.p: THE right Aloe Hepatica ought to be of a fine light Liver colour, fine and clear, not very foetid in ≈ømell; that which is called ≈øo he ‚Ä¢ e in England is nothing el≈øe but Aloe Caballina, of a ≈øtrong foetid ≈ømell, and very cour≈øe, fitter to be given to Hor≈øes than Men: it comes from Surrat in the Ea≈øt Indies.

div.head: * Aloe Barbados.
div.p: IS the ≈øame as the former, but rather finer, yet of a foetid ≈ømell; it comes in gourds, which is generally the be≈øt: ≈øome in pots is pretty good; that which comes in Casks is moi≈øt, and inferiour to the former.

div.head: * Ambra Gri≈øea.
div.p:
AMbergree≈øe, the be≈øt is of an Ash colour, ≈øomething ≈øpeckled, with little ≈ømall black and white ≈øpecks; it is of a mo≈øt fragrant, plea≈øant ≈ømell, clear from any dro≈øs, and not cru≈øty without, running a hot Needle ≈ølightly into it, there will i≈ø≈øue out a Fatne≈øs of a fragrant ≈øcent;
'tis brought from the Ea≈øt and We≈øt Indies (viz. Bermoodos, &c.) and ≈øometimes 'tis found in near parts adjacent: There was lately a piece di≈øcovered in a Sperma Ceti Whale in Ireland, ≈øomewhat like Ambergree≈øe 'tis never the wor≈øe if it does incline to a yellowi≈øh colour; ≈øometimes you will di≈øcover the beaks of Birds in it, which is a ≈øymptome of its truene≈øs: it has been ob≈øerved that Birds will generally ≈øtrike at it, and ≈øeveral pieces floating at Sea have by that means been taken up.

div.head: Ambra Nigra.
div.p: BLack Ambergree≈øe, the be≈øt cometh from the Ea≈øt Indies, being of a black colour, ≈øometimes ≈øpeckled with a few grey Specks: We have had in former times an Iri≈øh black Ambergree≈øe, which was more foetid than fragrant, breaking ≈øofti≈øh and very ≈øhining, but of late (tho' much enquired for) ≈øcarce to be had for Money.

div.head: * Amber Liquid.
div.p:
IS a very fine and fragrant Liquor of the ≈øame Conden≈øity, as a Stra≈øbourg Turpentine, of a pale reddi≈øh colour; it comes
from Aegypt, Chio, and the Straits.

div.head: Amygdala Amara.
div.p: BItter Almonds are to be cho≈øen fre≈øh, large, breaking white within, of a bright colour without, they come mo≈øt generally from Barbary, ≈øome few from Province, and other parts of France.

div.head: Amygdala Dulcis.
div.p: SWeet Almonds are to be cho≈øen as afore≈øaid, but of a ≈øweet ta≈øte, without rancor, the be≈øt are the Jordan, after them Province and Barbary Almonds.

div.head: Anacardia
div.p: IS the Fruit of an Indian Tree, like a Birds Heart, with Juice like Blood; it is by ≈øome called the Elephants Low≈øe; it is brought from Bantam in the Ea≈øt Indies.

div.head: Antimonium Crudum.
div.p:
CRude Antimony is a Mineral Body, in which the Metalline nature is fini≈øhed, con≈øi≈øting of Sulphur Mineral, of
Metallic Mercury indige≈øted, and of an earthly Sub≈øtance intermixt with Salt: That which is brought to us comes from Dantzick and Poland, which is in Loaves of a pretty length being larger ≈øtreak'd, and le≈øs foot in it than that which comes from France, which is in large, round, thick Loaves, full of foot, and nothing nigh ≈øo good as the former.

div.head: Antimonium Hungar.
div.p: OF all Antimonies, the Hungarian and Tran≈øylvanian Antimony is to be preferred, becau≈øe that it is of a purer Sulphur, and inbibeth a Golden Mineral; therefore are its ≈øtreaks more ≈øplendid and longer, of an ob≈øcure reddi≈øhne≈øs, which ≈øhoweth its goodne≈øs; 'tis ca≈øt in a Pyramid fa≈øhioned Loaf, and this Antimony is in all Medicines to be preferr'd before any other.

div.head: Antimonium Diaph.
div.p: DIaphoretick Antimony is a Chymical Preparation, with Nitre and Antimony, and Wa≈øhing, that it comes very white and light.

div.head: Antimonii Vitrum.
div.p: OR Stibium, is a Gla≈øs of Antimony, looks a tran≈øparent deep red, Chymically ≈øo prepared, and that mo≈øt in Am≈øterdam.

div.head: Antimonii Ceru≈ø≈øa
div.p: IS Chymically prepared from Antimony, &c. made here in Town, being very white.

div.head: Aqua Fortis.
div.p: OF Aqua Fortis there is in Druggi≈øts Shops ≈øold, viz. double and ≈øingle. It is a Chymical Preparation, drawn from Salt petre and Copperas, to ≈øeveral degrees; the ≈øtrength of it is known by pouring it upon the blade of a Knife, by its ≈øtrong ≈øcent, fum ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ g and eating in pre≈øently in the blade of a Knife, or any thing of Bra≈øs or Co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ er, as al≈øo by the quickly rotting a Pack-thred.

div.head: Aqua flor. Aurant.
div.p: ORange Flower Water is brought to us from Province and Nizza, in France, as al≈øo from Genoua and other parts of Italy. Its Goodne≈øs is only known by the rare odoriferous and fragrant Smell by dipping your Handkerchief, &c. in it.

div.head: Argentum Vivum.
div.p: QUick Silver is a Mineral Liquor, or a Metallic Volatile; the be≈øt is Virgin Quick Silver, or that which is ≈øometimes naturally found in the Earth, tho' mo≈øt of it is made of a Mineral which is called Cinnaber, by the force of Fire, as al≈øo drawn out of other Metals; 'tis found in quantities in Hungaria, Tran≈øylvania, Tyrol, and other parts of Germany, and ≈øome parts of Spain.

div.head: Aroma Equinum.
div.p: HOr≈øe Spice is a thing made here in England of ≈øeveral Ingredients, as Foenugrick, Turmerick, Long Pepper, &c. All ground together in Powder.

div.head: Auriculae Judae.
div.p: JEws Ears is a ≈øpungy Excre≈øcency out of Elder Trees, they are found here in England and mo≈øt parts of Europe.

div.head: * Auripigmentum.
div.p: ORpment is a ≈øecundary Sulphureou Mineral, but inflammable: the fine≈øt comes from Surrat in the Ea≈øt Indies, breaking of a ≈øhining Gold colour, there is a great deal in Saxony in Germany, but cour≈øer and lighter yellow, inclining to a green, more hard and rocky than the former.

div.head: Aerugo Aeris.
div.p: VErdigrea≈øe is a thing made out of Copper, which by the Evaporating of new Wine turns to a green Powder, and ≈øo gathered in Leather Bags, and brought to us from Mar≈øeilles in France; that which is of a dry and lively colour, breaking ea≈øily into Powder, is to be preferr'd.

div.head: Aes U≈øtum.
div.p: IS nothing el≈øe but the Scales of Copper Calcined in a Reverberatory Fire; which are ea≈øily reduced into a Calx by beating them in a Mortar.

div.head: Ar≈øenicum Album.
div.p: VVHite Rats-bane, the be≈øt of it breaks clear and tran≈øparent like Cry≈øtal, and comes out of Saxony, by way of Hamborough; it's nothing el≈øe but a fu≈øion of Orpment and Salt, and therefore not a natural but an artificial thing.

div.head: Ar≈øenicum Citrinum.
div.p: YEllow Ar≈øenick comes likewi≈øe out of Saxony; It is to be cho≈øen of a pure yellow colour, breaking clear within.

div.head: Ar≈øenicum Rubrum.
div.p:
BY ≈øome called Ro≈øe Alger, alias Ar≈øenic Sandarac, is of an Orange colour, if beaten to Powder, the mo≈øt pernicious of Poy≈øons; even outwardly applied, it produceth
horrible Effects, this comes from the places afore≈øaid.

div.head: Baccae Alkekengi, Winter Cherries.
div.p: THey grow here again≈øt a Wall in England, and in a great many other parts wild among≈øt the Vineyards. The Berries are in a husk re≈øembling red Cherries, but a little more of an Orange colour, being well dried, they will continue of a lively red colour, a little enclining to yellow.

div.head: * Baccae Coffee.
div.p:
COho Seeds, or Coffee, is a Berry which groweth upon a Shrub in the De≈øarts of Arabia Foelix, f ‚Ä¢ om whence it is carried through all the Grand Siegnior's Dominions even to the Ea≈øt Indies; the be≈øt comes now from the Ea≈øt Indies, being large, bright, a full ‚Ä¢ erry, and clean. Formerly that which came from Turky; (which generally looks a little greeni≈øh) was
be≈øt e≈øteemed; great quantities are yearly imported from both parts.

div.head: Baccae Hederae.
div.p: IVY Berries grow in England and all parts of Europe, they are to be cho≈øen of a good full growth and well dried, and gathered in the right ≈øea≈øon.

div.head: Baccae Juniperi.
div.p: JUniper Berries grow here and in all parts of Europe: the large≈øt and fre≈øhe≈øt of a good plea≈øant Smell, black without, and very green within, are to be preferred.

div.head: Baccae Lauri.
div.p: LAurberries, Bay Berries is a large Berry brought to us from Port a Port, of a very hot oleaginous ta≈øte, a little inclining to black, brown Kernels within, they come from ≈øeveral parts of the Straits.

div.head: Baccae Myrti.
div.p: MYrtilberries grow in Italy, France, and other hot Countries near the Rocks and Cliffs of the Sea, brought to us from Mar≈øeilles.

div.head: Baccae Kermes.
div.p: ALkermes Berries is of a lively red colour, very light, and ≈øoon broken, ≈øomething like a Fly within. They come from Italy, Venice, France, and Mar≈øeilles.

div.head: Bal≈øamum Capivi.
div.p: IS a Natural Bal≈øam flowing from a Bal≈øam Tree in Surinam in the We≈øt Indies, of an Aromatic Smell, hot and bitter ta≈øte, of a body clear, tran≈øparent, like Venice Turpentine, but exceeding all Turpentine for Goodne≈øs and Vertue.

div.head: * Bal≈øamum Judaicum.
div.p: BAlm of Gilead, by ≈øome called of Meccha, by other Bal≈øamum Syriacum, is a Bal≈øam much re≈øembling the former, but of a more condens'd Body; if ≈øome drops are poured into Water, it will ≈øpread upon the ≈øurface of the Water, and uphold a little piece of Tobacco Pipe; it is very fragrant, of Smell ≈øomewhat like Ro≈øemary and Sage Flowers: 'tis brought to us from Turky, and is ≈øaid to grow out of a thorny Tree in Arabia, Media and India.

div.head: * Bal≈øamum Peruanum.
div.p: NAtural Bal≈øam, Indian Bal≈øam is of a a very fragrant ≈øweet Smell, a reddi≈øh black colour, ≈øinking under Water; 'tis brought to us from Peru, and New Spain, in earthen Jars covered over with Leather.

div.head: Bal≈øamum Sulphuris,
div.p: IS nothing el≈øe but a Chymical Preparation made out of Flower of Brim≈øtone, and Oyl of Turpentine, till it comes to a mo≈øt curious Bal≈øamic conden≈øity, red like a Ruby, ≈øometimes 'tis made with Oyl of ≈øweet Fennel, or Annis-≈øeed.

div.head: * Bal≈øamum Tolutanum.
div.p: BAl≈øam Tolu, is a Bal≈øamous Liquor, of a red, inclining to a Gold colour, con≈øi≈øting between a liquid and a thick Body, very glutinous, where ever it fa≈øtneth it ≈øticks clo≈øe to it, and plea≈øant in Smell (and not nau≈øeous like other Bal≈øams) like the be≈øt of Lemons, and Ja≈ømin Flowers; 'tis brought from Carthagena, by the Natives called Tolu, out of the Spani≈øh We≈øt Indies, in large and ≈ømall Callaba≈øtes.

div.head: Bolus Armenus.
div.p:
FIne Bole or Bolus verus, it taketh its name from Armenia, a Country beyond Greece, and is often brought from Turky and the Straits; 'tis al≈øo digged in Germany, nea ‚Ä¢
Wirtemberg, and great ≈øtore, its ≈øaid, may be had in St. Helena; the fine≈øt is of a fatti≈øh red colour, being put to the tongue will ea≈øily ≈øtick fa≈øt to it, being put in the water will as ea≈øily di≈ø≈øolve, as Butter in melting.

div.head: Bolus Communis.
div.p: Common Bole is a thing made here in England of Red-oaker and Whiteing, &c. the nearer it comes to the fine, the better e≈øteemed.

div.head: * Borax.
div.p: IS a thing made out of natural Borax or Tincal, being in a manner refined from its Dro≈øs, &c. is in pretty large Lumps, bigger than a Walnut, white, almo≈øt tran≈øparent, of ta≈øte not acid, but as it were urinous. It is refin'd here, and in Holland, and other parts of Europe.

div.head: Butyrum Je≈ø≈øamin.
div.p: JE≈ø≈øamin Butter is made out of the Je≈ø≈øamin Flowers and Lard, finely beaten in a Marble Mortar.

div.head: * Bang.
div.p: IS an Herb which comes from Bantam in the Ea≈øt Indies, of an Infatuating quality and pernicious u≈øe.

div.head: * Camphora.
div.p:
CAmphora or Camphor is a Gum of a Tree, of which there is great plenty in Japan, in Burneo and China, and other parts of the Ea≈øt-Indies, from whence it is brought to us in Duppers and Casks unrefined, being refined in large round Casks, is of a clear and almo≈øt tra≈øparent body, of a white Cry≈øtalline colour, and Odoriferous ≈øtrong ≈ømell, like the be≈øt Oyl of Spike, of a Volatile quality, ea≈øily di≈ø≈øolving,
being ≈øet on fire almo≈øt inextinguible, burning in Water and Air; and therefore of great u≈øe in Bombs, Carca≈ø≈øes, and other Fire-Works.

div.head: Cantharides.
div.p: CAntharides, or Spani≈øh Flies, is an In≈øect which groweth out of A≈øh-Tree-leaves; they are found in Meadows and Corn-fields; they are to be cho≈øen of a very lively green Colour, fre≈øh, whole and large, without Du≈øt, of a longi≈øh body. They come from France, Spain, Italy and Germany.

div.head: Cap. Papaver. Albi.
div.p: WHite Poppy head grows here in mo≈øt parts of England, Germany, France, &c. being of very large Heads; a white Poppy ≈øeed within: Sometimes the Seeds are brought out of France, being very white and of a ≈øweet ta≈øte, cau≈øing ≈øleepine≈øs.

div.head: Carabe.
div.p:
AMber, or Succinum, is a bituminous Sub≈øtance; or as ≈øome ≈øay, a Re≈øin of the Earth, and out of old Trees
thorowly dige≈øted; and from thence traduced into the Seas. The be≈øt is reckoned the White, which is ≈øaid to be the fatte≈øt; the yellow or clear Amber colour the next to it; ≈øome of three or four pounds a piece in weight. They make ≈øeveral Toyes of it, as Necklaces, Knife hafts, Cabinets, &c. and a great deal is carried to the Ea≈øt-Indies; the brown and black is the wor≈øt, only fit to draw Oyl and Salt; it is found near the Sea-≈øhores of Pru≈ø≈øia, and brought to Sale at Coningsberg.

div.head: * Cariophylli.
div.p: CLoves, or little Cloves, ≈øo called, becau≈øe 'tis ≈øaid they are beaten down before their full growth; tho≈øe are to be cho≈øen which are black, oyly, very hot in the ta≈øt, of a ≈øtrong odoriferous ≈ømell. There is another ≈øort which is called Antophylli, or Mother Cloves, which are large, full grown, but not ≈øo good as the former.

div.head: * Carpobal≈øamum.
div.p:
SHould be the Berry that comes from the ≈øame Tree, out of which Balm
of Gilead is made, of a longi≈øh ≈øhape; ≈øomewhat like to Cubebs in the ta≈øte; growing formerly in Pale≈øtina, then in Syria, but now tran≈øplanted into Egypt: but here in England we u≈øe the Jamaica Pepper, or Pimento, of which the ≈ømalle≈øt, rounde≈øt, and of a fragrant ≈ømell, (like Cloves) is to be preferred.

div.head: * Ca≈ø≈øia Fi≈øtularis.
div.p: IS the fruit of a Tree growing in long Canes, or Pipes, hanging very full and thick on the Branches: The be≈øt of all cometh from the Ea≈øt-Indies, and great quantities u≈øed to be brought from Bantam; it is of a thin rind, full of Pulp, and free from ratling: There are al≈øo quantities brought from the We≈øt-Indies, as St. Martenico, Gardelup, Bra≈ø≈øil, &c. of which ≈øort the Pipes are generally large and thick rinded, and not ≈øo pulpy within, and therefore worth a great deal le≈øs than the Ea≈øt-India ≈øort.

div.head: * Ca≈øtoreum Angl. Nov.
div.p:
NEw-England Ca≈øtor is the wor≈øt of all Ca≈øtors, being in longi≈øh, hard, and thin Cods, the ≈øub≈øtance within
more like Re≈øin than Ca≈øtor; they are the Cods from a Beaver: There is a ≈øort which has been lately brought from Hud≈øon's Bay, which is in ≈øhape of the Cods ≈øomething like New-England, but in Quality and goodne≈øs far exceeding it, being moi≈øter in the Cods, and the inner ≈øub≈øtance of a very ≈øtrong ≈ømell and ta≈øte, little inferiour to the Poland ≈øort.

div.head: Castoreum Ru≈ø≈øiae.
div.p: IS the Cods or Stones of a Beaver; The be≈øt of all Ru≈ø≈øia, or other Ca≈øtor, is that of Siberia, of a ≈øtrong and grave ≈ømell, of good large round Cods well fed, neither too dry nor too moi≈øt, if cut of a red liver colour. There is another ≈øort which is brought from Poland and Dantzick, which is generally fat and moi≈øt, and nothing near ≈øo good as the former.

div.head: Cera Alba.
div.p:
WHite Wax is made out of yellow Wax, the ≈øame being by a certain Engine turned into ≈ømall Flakes and Shivers, and bleached in the Sun, will turn white as Snow; which afterwards
is ca≈øt into round Cakes, ≈øome thicker, others thinner, that is to be cho≈øen, which ≈ømells well and chaws hard, not being mixt with Sheeps or Lambs Suet, and and that which looketh very white without the lea≈øt ca≈øt of any yellowne≈øs.

div.head: Cera Flava.
div.p: YEllow wax is made here in England from the Bee-hives, of a firm body, and plea≈øant ≈ømell, it is of a good lively Colour, and made up in round Cakes of ≈øeveral bigne≈øs: That which comes from Dantzick and other parts of the Ea≈øt Country, is likewi≈øe very good, and free from Adulteration. That which comes from Guinea and African parts, is nothing near ≈øo good, being ca≈øt in Sand and adulterated, and of no good Colour.

div.head: Ceterach.
div.p: CEterach is an Herb which comes out of Germany; 'tis of a very ‚Ä¢ ender ≈øub≈øtance, of a light browni≈øh Colour, ea≈øily running to du≈øt.

div.head: Chamaepitys.
div.p: GRound Pine, alias, Iva arthetica, is a Herb which is in ≈øandy ground here in England, and other parts of Europe, having a blewi≈øh Flower.

div.head: Chalybs Crud.
div.p: STeel is nothing el≈øe but Iron in the be≈øt way purged; that which comes from Styria and Venice, is generally reputed the be≈øt: Other ≈øorts come from Cologne and Berg≈øland; but inferiour to the former.

div.head: Chalybs Preparat.
div.p: IS Steel Chymically prepared by a ≈øtrong Acid, &c.

div.head: Ceru≈ø≈øa Veneta.
div.p:
CEru≈ø≈øa, or fine white Lead of Venice, is in little fine Loaves, wrapped up in blew Papers, brought over to us being very heavy; formerly it u≈øed to be brought from Venice, now great ≈øtore is imported from Holland; but that
which is made here in England, is better e≈øteemed.

div.head: Cinnabaris Factitia.
div.p: VErmilion, or made Cinnaber, is of a very fine lively red colour, made out of Quick-Silver and Brim≈øtone by the Chymical Art. Fir≈øt, it was made only in Italy; afterward great quantities were imported from Holland; and now it is likewi≈øe made in England: The goodne≈øs is known by its pure fine red colour.

div.head: Cinnabaris Nativa.
div.p: NAtural Cinnaber is a Mineral con≈øi≈øting of Sulphur and live Mercury; ≈øome doth re≈øemble a red Stone; the fine≈øt is a very ≈ømooth drop of a pure red, gli≈øtering and ≈øhining like the be≈øt of Vermilion; it is ≈øaid to be found in Lybia; but of late, the Dutch have brought the fine≈øt yet ≈øeen from Japan, out of the Ea≈øt-Indies: That which is found in Germany, is rocky and ≈øtony, and far inferiour to the former.

div.head: * Cochinille.
div.p: IS a fine little Berry, breaking in a very dark red Powder, grayi≈øh coloured without; in ≈øhape like that In≈øect, called Lady-bird, but ≈øomething le≈øs, and therefore by many believed to be a Flie, (or an In≈øect) which cannot be, that any ≈øuch rich colour can be in any ≈øuch Creature: The true≈øt account I ever could learn, is, that ≈øome Flies and In≈øects fa≈øtening upon the leaves (which are ≈øharp as Needles) of a certain Shrub, on which your We≈øt-India Shoak-bears do grow, cau≈øes a kind of a bli≈øter, turning very red at fir≈øt, and grayi≈øh the out≈øide. After the Indians do rub all the other part of the leaf when dry, and thus the Cochinille is produced: Others think it only the blo≈ø≈øom of a tender Herb, taken off before it flowers; 'tis of an excellent colour, of which all the fine≈øt Scarlet and Purple are dyed. Brought from New Spain and Mexico.

div.head: Corallina.
div.p:
IS nothing el≈øe but a Sea-mo≈øs, (Mu≈øcus Marinus) growing in little white
threads, as ≈ømall Vipers to the Rock, like the Mo≈øs to a Tree, being good, is very white in longi≈øh Strings, like the unrifling of a cour≈øe white Linnen; ≈øome of an inch long, ≈øome ≈øhorter, 'tis of a ≈øalti≈øh ta≈øte, the ≈ømell re≈øembling to Oi≈øters.

div.head: Corallium Album.
div.p: WHite Coral is ≈øaid to be a ≈øtony Juice growing under water in the Sea; ≈øome like the ≈ømall branches of a Tree, others of ≈øeveral forms and ≈øhapes, (I have ≈øeen pieces of half a hundred Weight, covering pieces of the Wrack where the Silver was fetcht out) the be≈øt of it is that which is pure, white and clear, almo≈øt tran≈øparent; free from Dro≈øs, re≈øembling almo≈øt the white Wax: It comes generally from the We≈øt-Indies, and other parts near Spain and France; there is a cour≈øe ≈øort like to pieces of Tobacco-Pipes, ≈øome ≈ømall like Sugar-Confects, is better; but the be≈øt, is of good hand≈øome clear Branches, and very clear and white.

div.head: Corallium Rubrum.
div.p: REd Coral, of a mo≈øt pure red colour, like Vermillion when polli≈øhed, and in large Branches, ≈øuch as u≈øed to be tran≈øported to the Ea≈øt-Indies, is be≈øt. But for Phy≈øical u≈øes, a ≈ømall little Sprig ≈øort is u≈øed likewi≈øe; that of a pure red is to be preferred; the pale ≈øcruffy ≈øort is nothing near ≈øo good: It is brought from the Tyrrhene and Sioilian Seas, as likewi≈øe, ≈øome parts of Italy, and is poli≈øhed at Naples.

div.head: Cornu Alcis.
div.p: THe Horn of an Elck is of ≈øeveral ≈øhapes, but that which is be≈øt for u≈øe, is a broad, ≈ølat, thick, heavy Horn, a little hollowi≈øh at one ≈øide; if white within, fit for ra≈øping; is in ≈øome ca≈øes to be preferred before Harts-horn.

div.head: Cornu Cervi.
div.p:
HArts-horn, or Stags horn, of which the be≈øt come out of Germany; the large with white and clear tips, of a good fre≈øh colour without, and very
white within, are be≈øt; tho≈øe which come from the Ea≈øt-Countreys, Scotland and Norway, are not ≈øo good.

div.head: Cornu Rhinocerotis.
div.p: THe Rhinoceros horn is of a dark browni≈øh colour, with a ≈øharp point, mo≈øtly bendeth Half-Moon fa≈øhion, but the Root very broad and heavy: I have ≈øeen ≈øome of three foot in length; they are brought over from the Ea≈øt-Indies.

div.head: Cornu Unicornu.
div.p: THe Unicorns horn is ≈øometimes eight foot and more in length, others of a ≈ømaller ≈øize; they are very ≈øharp pointed, running taper all along, and twi≈øted of the colour of Ivory, and a finer grain than any Ivory, and very white within, they are not of a four leg'd Creature, like to a Hor≈øe, but come from a Fi≈øh, and therefore a Sea-Unicorn; they are brought from the Straits Davids, near the North-Pa≈ø≈øage.

div.head: Cortex Cappari Rad.
div.p: CAper-bark is of the Roots of a Caper Tree, or rather a Shrub, whereupon the Capers grow; the Bark is be≈øt which is bright, a fair Pai≈ønip colour, and ≈øomewhat large, and not Worm eaten.

div.head: * Cortex Ca≈ø≈øiae Ligneae.
div.p:
CA≈ø≈øia-Lignea is of ≈øeveral ≈øorts, the mo≈øt and be≈øt for Phy≈øical Pre≈øcription, is the quill ≈øort, (being made up in ≈ømall bundles) the thickne≈øs of a Goo≈øe Quill, generally ≈øixteen Inches, or thereabouts, long, of a bright light Cinnamen colour, of a ≈øweet, but not ≈øharp biting, &c. of a glutenous ta≈øt when chawed. There is another ≈øort, which is called the Tramboon ≈øort, of which there is one kind in bundles like Clove-Park, of a very hot biting ta≈øt, breaking gummy as it were, and blacki≈øh within like Clove-Bark, which is very good al≈øo; then likewi≈øe another ≈øort much like this la≈øt, in large thick rowles as big as a Thigh, which proves pretty good and ≈øtrong, but is of a very dark
colour. Others of the Tramboon ≈øort, is like the ≈ømall Cinnamon, ≈øomething of the ≈øame ta≈øt, but not ≈øo ≈øtrong, but more woody, and of a wor≈øe colour; all come from the Ea≈øt-Indies.

div.head: Cortex Cinnamomi.
div.p: CInnamon is a Bark of the Cinnamon Tree, which groweth upon the I≈øland Zeylon, of a light bright Cinnamon colour, of a very hot, but very plea≈øant odoriferovs ta≈øt, of a fragrant ≈øcent in the very handling of it, in Pipes about a yard in length; the ≈ømalle≈øt and thinne≈øt Bark is generally be≈øt.

div.head: Cortex Citri.
div.p: CItron Peels come from Spain and Portugal; tho≈øe which look of a lively yellow colour and fragrant ≈ømell, are be≈øt.

div.head: * Cortex Elatherii.
div.p:
IS a Bark ≈øo called from the name of an I≈øland which is in the We≈øt-Indies; 'tis a round curled Bark, (≈øomething like Je≈øuits Bark) of a very hot
ta≈øt, and fragrant ≈ømell when burned, therefore it is often u≈øed to ≈øweet-≈øcent Tobacco.

div.head: Cortex E≈øulae Rad.
div.p: IS a ≈ømall bright Bark, growing in England, Germany, &c.

div.head: Cortex Granatorum.
div.p: ARe the Peels of Pomegranate-Apples, of which, greate≈øt part are brought to us from Portugal; the large≈øt, reddi≈øh without, and a bright yellow within, are to be preferred. They grow al≈øo abundantly in Turky, Italy, Egypt, France and Spain, and other parts of the World.

div.head: Cowitch.
div.p: IS the down of a large Cod, like a Pea≈øe-cod, of a brown colour, like dark Cinnamon, the ≈øaid Cowitch being nothing el≈øe but a down covering the ≈øaid Cods, called Cowitch, becau≈øe of its provoking itching and ≈øcratching, is of no other u≈øe, but to play Tricks and Waggery with: It cometh from Jamaica.

div.head: * Cortex Guajaci.
div.p: THe Bark of Lignum Vitae, or Lignum Guajacum, that which is fre≈øh and new, and taken from the Tree, when it is alive and green, is to be preferred, though a great many u≈øe al≈øo the dry Bark; the Lignum Vitae groweth abundantly in Jamaica, and in mo≈øt of the American I≈ølands.

div.head: Cortex Limonum.
div.p: LEmon Peels are gathered here from the Lemmons, tho≈øe in Holland and other parts, they import great quantities from Portugal; tho≈øe which are of a good colour and ≈øcent, are be≈øt.

div.head: * Cortex Peruanus.
div.p:
JE≈øuites Bark, China chinna, quin quina, Ca≈øcarello, Cortex Patrum, is the Bark of a Tree which groweth in Peru, the Bark being not too large, but from the ≈ømaller Twigs curled, a lively colour, a little more dark yellowi≈øh than Cinnamon, of a bitter ta≈øte, breaking ≈øhiningly, ≈øometimes very rough, and a
whiti≈øh outward Bark are to be cho≈øen: That which is very thick, dark coloured and flat, is nothing near ≈øo good.

div.head: * Cortex Sa≈ø≈øafrae Lign.
div.p: THe Bark of Sa≈ø≈øafras is of a reddi≈øh bright colour, and ≈øtrong ta≈øte: It is brought from New-England.

div.head: Cortex Tamari≈øci.
div.p: IS the Bark of a Tree which groweth in Germany, along the Rhine and Danube, in gravelly places; it comes in large bundles, the Bark looking an Iron gray without, and light brown within.

div.head: * Cortex Winteranus.
div.p: WInter Bark is a whiti≈øh Bark brought to us from the We≈øt-Indies, of a very hot biting ta≈øt, pretty large and thick of Sub≈øtance.

div.head: Cranium Humanum.
div.p:
THe Scull of a Man ought to be of ≈øuch an one which dieth a violent Death, (as War, or Criminal Execution)
and never buried: Therefore tho≈øe of Ireland are here be≈øt e≈øteemed, being very clean and white, and often covered over with Mo≈øs.

div.head: Cremor Tartari.
div.p: IS a refining, and boyling, and ≈øhooting of French Argol, which is brought to us in quantities from France, that which is be≈øt, looks very white and clear, not yellowi≈øh, and the nearer it re≈øembles Cry≈øtal Tartari, (which is made of Rheni≈øh Argol) the better it is to be e≈øteemed.

div.head: Crocus Anglicus.
div.p:
ENgli≈øh Saffron is mo≈øtly brought out of Cambridge≈øhire, and gathered near Saffron‚ñ™Walden, made up in Cakes; that which is of very fiery red, and blood red colour, of a very ≈øtrong ≈ømell, of a hotti≈øh ta≈øt, ≈øtriking a very good Tincture, of a large Leaf, tough and firm in the tearing, is to be preferred: That which is of a pale yellowi≈øh colour, old and decayed, is by nothing near ≈øo good, therefore the newe≈øt is to be cho≈øen before any, unle≈øs the year before
brought forth that which was larger, richer, and of a better colour.

div.head: Crocus Hi≈øpanicus.
div.p: SPani≈øh Saffron comes in loo≈øe Leaves, and is generally oyled over; that which is of a large Leaf, good lively colour, and well ≈øcented, as above-≈øaid, is to be cho≈øen.

div.head: Crocus Martis.
div.p: IS a Chymical Preparation; being made of Iron by a Calcination in a Reverberatory Fire, till it cometh off in a fine pure red Crocus.

div.head: Crocus Metallorum.
div.p: THe Saffron of Metalls is made of Antimony, Salnitre, (and ≈øometimes fine Tartar) put to a Fu≈øion and Detonation, the Faeces being ≈øeparated, produceth a fine Liver-coloured Crocus.

div.head: * Cubebae.
div.p:
CUbebs is an Aromatick Fruit, ≈øomewhat like to Pepper, being a little
le≈øs, of a hot Aromatick ta≈øt: They grow in the I≈øle of Java, and are generally brought from Bantam.

div.head: Cu≈øcuta.
div.p: DOdder is an Herb which is inclining to a red colour, and very ≈øtalky; it groweth in mo≈øt parts of Europe.

div.head: Crystallus.
div.p: CRystal is a ≈øtone much like to frozen Ice; that which is u≈øed in Phy≈øick ought to be pure, clear and whiti≈øh, tran≈øparent like Water; 'tis abundantly found in Germany, Bohemia, Hungaria, Cypres, France, &c.

div.head: Chelae Cancrorum.
div.p: CRabs-Claws are the tips of the larger Sea-Crabs gathered here in England, and near adjacent places, the large≈øt being mo≈øt de≈øired, being black on the tips, and red underneath.

div.head: Cicerum Rub.
div.p:
REd Cicer is a kind of a Pea of a bright fre≈øh red colour, a little
≈øharp point at one end of it, full and large, and not black or dark; they come from Italy.

div.head: Cicer Album.
div.p: IS the ≈øame as afore≈øaid, being only of a white colour in≈øtead of red; they come from Italy, as the former.

div.head: * Colocynthis.
div.p: COloquintida, Coloquints is a wild Fruit, not unlike to Oranges, which being pared, is very white and light, full of Seeds, coming from Egypt, the ta≈øte ≈øo bitter, even exceeding Gall.

div.head: Coculus Indus.
div.p: IS a Berry which is brought from the Ea≈øt-Indies, a little more round and larger than Bay-berry, hollow within, and of a browni≈øh colour: They bring them likewi≈øe from Turky.

div.head: Colophonia.
div.p:
IS nothing but a tran≈øparent, clear, and yellowi≈øh Re≈øin, which will ea≈øily
be beaten into a (whiti≈øh) Powder: 'Tis brought to us from France.

div.head: Dactylus.
div.p: DAtes is a Fruit coming from Barbary, ≈øome from A≈øia: The be≈øt are large, long in ≈øhape, yellow colour, inclining a little to red; (≈øome a little darker) if the ≈øtone within is very white, and a little Cap upon their tops, ≈øhoweth that they are fre≈øh, their ta≈øte is ≈øweet, ≈øomewhat like to Malago-Wine.

div.head: Dens Apri.
div.p: THe Tu≈øh of a wild Boar is crookedly bent, ≈øomething like to a Sea-hor≈øe Tooth, but a great deal le≈øs; not above two or three Inches long, as white as Ivory, ≈øharp at one end, and hollow at the other: They come from Germany.

div.head: Dens Equi Marini.
div.p: THe Sea-hor≈øe Tooth is of a large bigne≈øs, ≈øome of four, five, or ≈øix pound weight, crookedly bent like a Half-Moon, white like Ivory: They are found in the We≈øt-Indies, Hud≈øons Bay, Greenland, and many other parts.

div.head: Diapente.
div.p: DIapente, is a Compo≈øition made by every Druggi≈øt, for the u≈øe and cure of Hor≈øes.

div.head: Ebor. Ra≈øurae.
div.p: THe ≈øhavings of Ivory, being made by the Ivory Comb-makers and Turners; the large≈øt, white≈øt, and cleane≈øt, are be≈øt.

div.head: ‚Ä¢ lixir Proprietatis.
div.p: IS a Chymical Preparation made of the be≈øt of Saffron, Myrrh and Aloes, &c. which is known by the ta≈øt, as likewi≈øe by the good tincture from the Saffron.

div.head: Epithymum.
div.p: EPithymum, is a kind of a Dodder which groweth over Time, like a Silk, or a Cob-web, of a brown reddi≈øh colour, that which has a good fragrant ≈ømell, and fewe≈øt ≈øtalks, is to be preferred. It comes from Turky, Italy, and other parts of the Straits.

div.head: Ens Veneris.
div.p: IS a Chymical Preparation made of Copper, Sal Armoniack, &c. That which is good, is very light; of a yellowi≈øh Orange colour, is made here in Town.

div.head: Flores Balau≈øt.
div.p: ARe the blo≈ø≈øoms of the Pomegranate Tree, of a very lively Scarlet red colour, (though they are dried) pretty large, they come in great quantities from Turky, ≈øometimes al≈øo from Portugal, Italy and Spain,: They grow here in England, and many other parts.

div.head: Flores Chamaemeli.
div.p: CAmomil Flowers, of which the double is called Roman Camomil-Flowers, being mo≈øt fragrant, and whiter than the ≈øingle, the ≈øame being yellow within, and white at the edge: They grow here in England, Germany, and mo≈øt parts of Europe.

div.head: Flores Meliloti.
div.p:
MElilot Flower is of a yellow colour, growing here in England, in ≈øtony places be≈øt: It is in its Flowers
the whole Summer, the ≈ømell re≈øembling ≈øomewhat near to Honey.

div.head: Flores Origani.
div.p:
ORiganum, the be≈øt which is liked of here in England, re≈øembleth the ≈øweet Marjarom, 'tis nothing el≈øe but a wild Marjarom, growing in Spain, Portugal, Italy, and other hot Countries, of a fragrant ≈ømell, betwixt Marjarom and Time, being in knotty Flowers, and free from Stalks, and of a light browni≈øh colour. It is generally brought from Ve
‚Ä¢ ice and Cadiz.

div.head: Flores Staechados.
div.p: SAechas is a Flower pretty large, (much of the ≈øhape of large Hops) of a fragrant ≈ømell when growing, the Flowers are yellow and blewi≈øh, but when dried up, of a Beer colour, or light brown in knobs: the large≈øt not broken, well ≈øcented, are be≈øt, which come from the Straits, Italy and Spain: There is a blewi≈øh ≈øort which comes from Mar≈øeilles, but is not ≈øo well liked of.

div.head: Flores Sulphuris
div.p: IS nothing el≈øe but rough Brim≈øtone ≈øublimed by a Chymical way; it is to be cho≈øen, that which is fine, light and ≈øoft, not har≈øh, of a fine lively yellow colour, almo≈øt in≈øipid in ta≈øte, di≈ø≈øolving in the Mouth.

div.head: Folia Betonicae.
div.p: BEtony Leaves are gathered here in England, and mo≈øt parts of Europe, their Flowers being of a Purple colour; the be≈øt are tho≈øe which are gathered in May.

div.head: Folia Dictamni Cret.
div.p: DIttany Leaves grow in Candia‚ñ™ Dalmatia, Morea, &c. the be≈ø ‚Ä¢ are in large Leaves, well covered with Willow-green, rough Cotton as it were upon them; ≈øometimes with Purple Flowers: Tho≈øe Leaves which are thi ‚Ä¢ and bald, are to be rejected, they come from Italy.

div.head: * Folia Malabathri.
div.p:
FOlium Indiae, Folium Ca≈ø≈øiae, is brought to us from the Ea≈øt Indies, groweth plentifully in Cambaja near the Water
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ de; the Leaf is large and broad, longer than a Lawrel leaf, not quite ≈øo broad; that is to be cho≈øen which is green, of a ≈øtrong ≈ømell, Cinnamon like, and that which is fre≈øh, not black or decayed.

div.head: Folia Ro≈øarum Rubrar.
div.p: REd-Ro≈øe-Leaves come out of France, ≈øometimes great ≈øto ‚Ä¢ e are gathered in England, of a ≈øweet ≈ømell, lively, dark red colour, choice ought to be made.

div.head: Folia Scordii.
div.p: SCordium, or wild Germander, groweth in and near wateri≈øh places here in England, and many places of Europe.

div.head: * Folia Sennae Aleppo.
div.p:
ALeppo Senna, is the cour≈øe≈øt of all Senna, (except the Ea≈øt-India) being generally full of Stalks, &c. of a ≈øhorter
Leaf, it is to be cho≈øen of a good ≈øtrong ≈ømell, not mu≈øty, green, of a pal ‚Ä¢ colour, and well clean≈øed.

div.head: * Folia Sennae Alexand.
div.p:
ALexandria Senna, is the be≈øt of al ‚Ä¢
Senna, of a large and long leaf, ‚Ä¢ fre≈øh ≈ømell, free from Stalks, and ≈ømall‚ñ™ of a lively colour, and a very goo ‚Ä¢ ≈øcent.

div.head: Folia Soldonellae.
div.p: SEA-Colwort, or Bindweed, is an Her ‚Ä¢ of a green leaf, growing near Maritim places in Italy, France and Zealand‚ñ™ from thence 'tis brought to us.

div.head: Folia Tu≈ø≈øilaginis.
div.p: THe leaves of Colts-foot grow her ‚Ä¢ in England, and mo≈øt part of Europe.

div.head: * Gallae.
div.p: GAuls, is a thing which groweth upon Oaks (of a certain kind) in Turky, more in u≈øe by Dyers and Salters, than Druggi≈øts; the be≈øt ≈øort are the Aleppo Gauls, and the be≈øt of them, tho≈øe which are blew and heavy, tho≈øe which are yellowi≈øh, inclining to red, (as mo≈øt of the Smyrna ≈øort) are not ≈øo much e≈øteemed: They are brought from Turky.

div.head: * Grana Paradi≈øi.
div.p: MAllagetta, is of a dark reddi≈øh colour, hot ta≈øte like Pepper: They are brought from Guinea.

div.head: * Gutta Gamba.
div.p:
CAmbogium, Gutta-Gum, is an in≈øpi≈ø≈øated Juice of a Plant, but not well known of what Herb: The ≈øame is brought from China, the colour is not unlike to the fine≈øt Curcuma; a fine yellow,
pure, inclining to an Orange colour‚ñ™ without Dro≈øs, pure and clean, in round Rowles and Cakes, ea≈øily di≈ø≈øolving, when touched with wet, or the Tongue, wil ‚Ä¢ turn whiti≈øh, or of a milky Sub≈øtance.

div.head: * Gum Ammoniacum.
div.p: Gum-Ammoniack is in fine little drops, the be≈øt is loo≈øe, ≈øomewhat like fine Olibanum, but in le≈øs drops, white within, and yellow without, ≈ømelling like to Ca≈øtoreum, of a bitter ta≈øte, it will ea≈øily ≈øtick to the Fingers, and ≈øo it often cometh all in one Ma≈øs or Lump; it is brought from Turky and Ea≈øt Indies, growing near the place where the Oracle of Hammon was, from whence 'tis thought to take its name.

div.head: * Gum Animi.
div.p: HEre that which is called Gum Animi, is called beyond the Seas Copal, and ≈øo Vice ver≈øa; the Gum here meant, is hard, tran≈øparent, rough without, like Gum Senica; it is brought from Guinea.

div.head: * Gum Arabicum.
div.p: GUm Arabick, Gummi Thebaicum, Gum Babylon cometh from a ≈ømall Tree growing near the Water, of a white, clear, and tran≈øparent colour: 'Tis brought to us from Turky, and other parts of the Straits.

div.head: * Gum A≈øa faetida.
div.p: STinking A≈øa (by ≈øome called Devilsdirt) are the Tears (or Lachryma) of a Tree called La≈øeris, growing in Syria, Lybia, and Media, the fine≈øt is in pure fine, white and clean drops, free from Stalks and other mixture, of a very ≈øtrong foetid or ≈øtinking ≈ømell, even exceding Garlike; 'tis adulterated with flower Sagapenum, &c. It is brought from the Ea≈øt-Indies and the Straits.

div.head: Gum Cera≈øorum.
div.p: GUM. from a Cherry-Tree is of a brown red colour, ≈øofti≈øh and clammy; 'tis found i≈ø≈øuing out of Cherry-trees here in England, and all parts of Europe.

div.head: * Gum Carannae.
div.p: G∆≤m Caragna is a ≈øofti≈øh re≈øinous Gum, being very tough, of a darki≈øh Olive colour (inclining to a Musk colour) being ≈øoft, conden≈øeth; being brought from the Spani≈øh We≈øt-Indies, from a place called Cartagena, being of an odoriferous ≈ømell.

div.head: * Gum Copal.
div.p: IS a whiti≈øh ≈øofti≈øh Gum (as it is here in England e≈øteemed) of an indifferent good ≈ømell, inclining to a yellowi≈øh white colour, much like to the ordinary Frankincen≈øe, but of a better ≈ømell; It comes from the Spani≈øh We≈øt-Indies.

div.head: Gum Bdellium.
div.p: 'TIs the Tear (or Lachryma) of a thorny Tree growing in Arabia, India and Media, 'tis of a bitter ta≈øte, fat in feeling, of a fragrant ≈ømell, ≈øomewhat ≈øofti≈øh, not ea≈øily to be beaten in a Mortar, of a light browni≈øh colour, (like bright and fre≈øh Prunelloes) and ≈øome of it black.

There is another ≈øort which here is mo≈øt de≈øired, which cometh among≈øt Gum Senica, and a little re≈øembling it, or like large pieces of Olibanum, which is ea≈øily beaten into Powder, but by the Learned, not looked upon ≈øo true as the former.

div.head: * Gum Benzoin.
div.p: IS very well ≈øcented, odoriferous and fragrant, the be≈øt is as if it were marbled, or intermixt with white and light brown, or dark yellowi≈øh ≈øpecks, breaking very ea≈øily, being rubbed betwixt the Hands, of a mo≈øt plea≈øant fragrancy; it may al≈øo be di≈øtingui≈øhed by throwing ≈øome ≈ømall Powder upon Coal: It is ≈øaid to be found in Samaria and Sidon, but that which is brought to us, cometh from the Ea≈øt-Indies. There are ≈øeveral ≈øorts, and of ≈øeveral qualities, ≈øome gray and white, which is pretty good, and another ≈øort all grayi≈øh, little white, but inclining to a dark brown, full of Dro≈øs, which is the wor≈øt.

div.head: Gum Elemi.
div.p: IS a Gum brought to us from the Spani≈øh We≈øt-Indies, (≈øome ≈øay al≈øo from Aethiopia) 'tis a very ≈øoft, bright, almo≈øt tran≈øparent Gum, white, inclining to yellow and green colour, ≈øo it ≈øeemed becau≈øe of its moi≈øture and ≈øoftne≈øs, it cometh in longi≈øh Cakes, rouled up in flags, if lighted on a Candle, or Fire, there will exhale a ≈øweet Fragrancy.

div.head: * Gum Guajaci.
div.p: IS a Gum i≈ø≈øuing out of a Lignum-vitae Tree, the be≈øt is in great pieces, clear like Ro≈øin, and breaks as ea≈øily, but of a green colour, that which is very clear and clean, breaking green, not filled up with Dro≈øs, (as ≈øome is) ought to be cho≈øen: It cometh from Jamaica, and other parts of the We≈øt-Indies.

div.head: * Gum Galbanum.
div.p:
IS a fatti≈øh and glutinous Gum, generally v ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y moi≈øt, and of a ≈øtrong flavour and ≈ømell, but ‚Ä¢ ragrant and plea≈øant withal, of a white, inclining to yellowi≈øh
colour, ≈øometimes full of little light Stalks and du≈øty; the cleare≈øt and pure≈øt is to be preferred, which cometh from Turky. Some hath lately been brought from the Ea≈øt-Indies, which hath been much adulterated, and nothing near ≈øo good as the former.

div.head: * Gum Euphorbium.
div.p: IS the Gum of a thorny Tree growing in Barbary, from thence 'tis imported to us. The be≈øt is „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ like a middling ≈øort of Manna in ≈ømall Flakes, a little ≈ømell, but very pernicious if taken, and hot in the No≈øe, will ≈øet it (≈øpeaking comparatively) all on a Fire.

div.head: Gum Hederae.
div.p: GUM of Ivy is found in mo≈øt part of Europe, as al≈øo here in England.

div.head: Gum Juniperi,
div.p:
OR Gum Sandaraca, cometh from Barbary, being in little longi≈øh tears or drops of a yellowi≈øh colour, almo≈øt tran≈øparent, very hard, and if beaten, it
will run in a very fine Powder, (which is called Pounce) 'tis abundantly u≈øed in Varni≈øh, gilding of Leather, &c.

div.head: * Gum Lacca.
div.p:
IS ≈øaid to be the Juice of a Tree, which is ≈øaid to be gathered by flying or winged Ants, (like as Bees do honey out of Flowers) which they induce about the Twigs and Branches of Trees. And thus we ≈øee ≈øtick I „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to us: 'Tis of a redd ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ght colour, not unlike to ≈ømall ‚Ä¢ ed Myrrh; that which is called Seed Lack, is in ≈ømall, bright reddi≈øh grains; the be≈øt is mo≈øt brighte≈øt, inclining to a yellowi≈øh colour, it ≈ømells ≈øweeti≈øh when burnt, (though unwhol≈øome) Shell Lack is made out of Seed Lack, being melted down of the fine≈øt Lack, and if fine, is of a reddi≈øh colour, and almo≈øt tran≈øparent. It cometh from Martaba, Malavar, and Sumatra in the Ea≈øt-Indies.

div.head: * Gum Labdanum.
div.p:
IS ≈øaid to be a liquor (or rather a Juice) out of a Tree called Ledon, of a blacki≈øh colour, cometh from Cypres in lumps, (which is generally the be≈øt) or in Pigs-tails,
rolled up in round tur≈øted Cakes (which are generally of a fragrant ≈ømell; but full of Sands) e≈øpecially when burnt, that which is fat, gummy, ea≈øily mollified, is be≈øt.

div.head: * Gum Myrrha.
div.p: MYrrh is a re≈øinous gummy Juice which groweth out of a Tree, of which they open the Bark, from thence it floweth in little and bigger drops, of a bright, fatti≈øh, and yellowi≈øh colour, of a fragrant ≈ømell and bitter ta≈øte, ≈ømooth and bright, not too heavy, the black and cru≈øty is not ≈øo good; 'tis ≈øaid to come from Arabia, but we have it brought from the Ea≈øt-Indies.

div.head: * Gum Olibanum.
div.p: 'TIs the true and right, the be≈øt are in little round white-yellowi≈øh drops, inclining a little to red, being in loo≈øe drops, and not run together; the be≈øt cometh from the Straits, very good cometh likewi≈øe from the Ea≈øt-Indies, but ≈øome of it being run together in lumps and turned black, being nothing near ≈øo much e≈øteemed.

div.head: * Gum Opopanax.
div.p: OPopanax is a fine reddi≈øh fragrant Gum, 'tis gathered from a Root, being the Juice of it, which thickned in the product; the be≈øt is in round loo≈øe drops, but being very glutinous, it will ≈øtick together in lumps; the be≈øt cometh from the Straits and Turky, and very good has been brought from the Ea≈øt-Indies, though of late they have very much adulterated the ≈øame in tho≈øe parts, viz. with Sagap ‚Ä¢ num, and Gum Ammoniacum.

div.head: * Gum Sagapenum.
div.p: SAgapenum, the Juice of Serapin, is a drop, or a Gum out of a Tree, growing in the Regions of Media, and ≈øome from Alexandria, being ≈øincere, very clear, the outward colour yellowi≈øh and reddi≈øh, inwardly white, of a ≈øharp ta≈øte, grave ≈ømell, a little re≈øembling Garlick.

div.head: * Gum Sarcocolla.
div.p:
IS a very ≈ømall Lachryma in little grains ‚Ä¢ ot much bigger than Gravel, of a yellow, reddi≈øh colour, of a bitteri≈øh and
≈øweeti≈øh ta≈øte, (like Liquori≈øh) it runs out of a thorny Tree, being excorticated; 'tis brought to us from the East-Indies.

div.head: * Gum Styrax Cal.
div.p: STorax Calamita, (√† cannarum Calamis ≈øic dicta) is the Gum of a T ‚Ä¢ ee, being a re≈øinous Juice, fat, ≈øoft in handling, of a mo≈øt ≈øweet fragrant ≈ømell, of a reddi≈øh colour, being mix'd with Bran is the wor≈øe for it; ≈øome with Saw du≈øt, which is the wor≈øt of all. This is generally brought from Turky and Alexandria.

div.head: * Gum Senica.
div.p: GUM Senica, is a Gum which cometh from Guinea, growing near a River called Senica, coming in large round Knobs, ≈øome reddi≈øh, ≈øome whiti≈øh, breaking very clear with ‚Ä¢ n and rough without: 'Tis brought to us from Holland and France, becau≈øe our African Company have no admittance in tho≈øe parts from whence they bring it.

div.head: * Gum Tacamahaca.
div.p: OF which there is two ≈øorts, one is brought over in ≈øhells, which is ≈øoft and whiti≈øh, of a mo≈øt plea≈øant and fragrant ≈ømell; the other in lumps, cometh in Che≈øts, which is nothing near ≈øo good, being generally dro≈ø≈øie; both come from New Spain.

div.head: * Gum Tragacanthum.
div.p: GUM Traganth, is a Gum which is brought from Turky; the be≈øt is very white, in little ≈ømall and curled Sprigs, that which is thick, brown and yellowi≈øh, is of little value; it will ea≈øily di≈ø≈øolve and turn into a Mucilage, &c.

div.head: Gluten Oris.
div.p: MOuth Glew is made of Icing Gla≈øs, Gum Senica and Traganth, in little long pieces, above an Inch and a half in length.

div.head: Granadillas Peru.
div.p: THe Granadilla is a black Berry (a ≈øort of Cataputia) of a longi≈øh ≈øhape, a little bigger than a Pine Kernel, of a black grayi≈øh Husk, a white Kernel within, (like the Barbados Nuts) not ≈øpeckled, but more a black colour, one half kernel being able to purge any body both upward and downward; they are light, and not heavy, and come from Peru in America.

div.head: Hordeum Gallicum.
div.p: FRench Barley, ≈øo called, becau≈øe it u≈øed to be brought out of France; 'tis nothing el≈øe but a Barley excorticated, or the upper Husk taken off by a certain Mill, which is made for that purpo≈øe; that which is round, white and clear, is the be≈øt: The ≈øame is now made here, and in Holland and Germany, &c.

div.head: Hordeum Perlatum.
div.p: PEarl Barley, ≈øo called, becau≈øe it doth very much re≈øemble the larger ≈øort of Seed-Pearl, being very round and ≈ømall, white, well-flowred over, fre≈øh, and not mu≈øty, the ≈ømaller the better, 'tis likewi≈øe done as afore≈øaid, but twice or thrice over to make it the finer, the be≈øt cometh from Germany, and in all, u≈øed to be preferred before the French Barley.

div.head: Ichthyocolla.
div.p:
Icing-Gla≈øs (in High-Dutch, Hau≈øon bla≈øs, Low-Dutch, Huy≈øen bla≈ø≈øen) is the product of a great Fi≈øh in the Danube, called in Latin Hu≈øo, of a glewy ≈øub≈øtance, without Bones, or gri≈ø≈øel Bones, (except in the Head) ≈øometimes four and twenty foot in length, and without Scales, he being de≈øirous of fre≈øh-water, cometh out of the Euxine Sea into the Danube, mo≈øt Icing Gla≈øs is made in Mu≈øcovy; the be≈øt
is the Patriarch ≈øort, four ≈øquare, very thin and white, almo≈øt tran≈øparent, the large Hor≈øe-≈øhooe ≈øort in thin Rings, and clear, called the Czars ≈øort, is the next; that which is yellow and brown within, a thick ≈øort, is inferiour; that in ≈øquare Books or Cakes, the wor≈øt of all.

div.head: Jujubae.
div.p: JUjubes is the fruit of a Tree called Ziziphus, of the bigne≈øs of a large Luke Olive, of a red colour like a Cherry, of ta≈øt of Rai≈øins of the Sun, having a Stone within like Prunes; the be≈øt are plum full of Pulp, and come from Italy; there is another ≈øort cometh from France, which are lean and hungry, a lighter red colour, but nothing near ≈øo good.

div.head: * Juncus Odoratus.
div.p: SQuinanth, alias Camelshay, is brought from Turky, and ≈øaid to grow in Arabia; that which is good, is of a ≈øtrong Aromatick ≈ømell, is well coloured, bright, of a good length, being often times made up in ≈ømall bundles, of a Pyramid fa≈øhion; the ≈øhort, grayi≈øh, and knotty ≈øort, is nothing near ≈øo much to be e≈øteemed.

div.head: Lac Sulphuris.
div.p: IS made of Flower of Brim≈øtone, and Salt of Tartar, by a Chymical Preparation, &c.

div.head: Lapis Amethy≈øtus.
div.p: THE Amethyst Stone, is of a dark Peach, or a live and light Purple, but a great deal paler; the be≈øt is of the Ea≈øt-Indies, or Oriental ≈øort, which is fit to be ≈øet in Rings, the other, and that which we u≈øe in Phy≈øick, is cour≈øer, and not ≈øo well coloured, which is brought to us out of Germany.

div.head: Lapis Amianthus.
div.p: IS a reddi≈øh Stone, the be≈øt coming from the Ea≈øt-Indies, tho≈øe which come from Bohemia, and other parts of Germany, are not ≈øo good: This Stone is of very little u≈øe, and very little ≈øold among≈øt Druggi≈øts.

div.head: Lapis Armenus.
div.p: THE Armenian Stone is of ≈øeveral ≈øpots, green, blewi≈øh, gold-colour'd, and a little inclining to black; this Stone is ≈øo called, becau≈øe it is brought from Armenia.

div.head: * Lapis Bezoar Occidentalis.
div.p: THE We≈øt-India Bezoar, cometh mo≈øtly from the Spani≈øh We≈øt-Indies, of ≈øeveral ≈øizes and bigne≈øs, ≈øome bigger than a Turky-Hens-Egg, others no bigger than a Ha≈øel-Nut, &c. The right is of an A≈øh-gray colour, ≈øome inclining to black; it ≈øhivers pieces from pieces, as well as the Oriental Bezoar, though in vertue by fair inferiour.

div.head: * Lapis Bezoar Orientalis.
div.p:
ORiental Bezoar is found in the inner parts of a Bea≈øt, of ≈øeveral Forms and Shapes, ≈øome round, Oval, longi≈øh and ≈øquare, and ≈øometimes in it a ≈øtraw, a bean, a ≈øtalk, a myrobalan Kernel, a Hair and pibble Stone; They are of ≈øeveral bigne≈øs, tho≈øe in ≈øort not exceeding a
dram; others of half, or one Ounce, but tho≈øe of two and three Ounces, are Rarities: They are of a dark green Olive colour, ≈ømooth and gli≈ø≈øening.

div.head: Lapis Calaminaris.
div.p: IS a grayi≈øh Stone, inclining to yellow and red; 'tis very heavy, and u≈øed in the making Bra≈øs out of Copper; and this Stone it comes from Germany, and ≈øeveral other parts, as al≈øo from Bri≈øtol and others parts of England.

div.head: * Lapis Contrayerva.
div.p: IS a made Stone of Contrayerva-Roots, Pearls, Coral, Amber, Crabs-eyes, and ≈øeveral other Ingredients, which after is gilded over, ≈ømelleth ≈øtrong of the Root.

div.head: Lapis Dentalis.
div.p: ARE littte bones out of a Haddock, or large Whiting, having two in every Head, they have as it were little Teeth at one ≈øide of them, from which, I ≈øuppo≈øe the name is derived.

div.head: Lapis Gagates.
div.p: JEtt, or Gett, is a bituminous Stone, very ≈øhining and hard; 'tis ≈øo called from Gaga, a River in Sicily: It comes likewi≈øe from A≈øia and Turky.

div.head: * Lapis de Goa.
div.p: GOA Stones, (by ≈øome not rightly called Lapis Ja≈øpar Antonicus) is a made Stone, (by the Portugees of Goa, being the chief place the Portugoi≈øe have near China in the Ea≈øt-Indies) ≈øome ≈øay of Seed-pearl, Bezoar, Gold, and other Ingredients; they are of a dark green colour, mixed with Gold Streaks, in ≈øhape almo≈øt of a large Olive, cutting very fine within, of a gray colour.

div.head: Lapis Granatas.
div.p: GRanat is a dark reddi≈øh Stone, ≈øome as large as a ≈ømall Pi≈øtol-≈øhot, others are ≈ømall like Guinea Grains: There is a great many found in Bohemia, and other parts of Germany, the cleare≈øt, and rede≈øt like Rubies, are the be≈øt.

div.head: Lapis Haematites.
div.p: SOme call it Blood-≈øtone, being of a blood red colour; the be≈øt are long, and do ≈øhiver ≈øharp at one end, like a Needle: They are found in Bohemia and Sile≈øia, near Bre≈ølaw.

div.head: Lapis Hyacinthus.
div.p: HYacinth Stones are of a light brown, or Beer colour, the be≈øt are ≈ømall, flat, and a rough out≈øide: There is a large ≈øort, which looks as if they were cut or polli≈øhed, of a red colour: The Oriental and be≈øt, are finer than both, of the colour of red fiery Flames. The former are found near a River in Sile≈øia, the other come from France, and the be≈øt from East-India.

div.head: Lapis Ja≈øpis.
div.p: IA≈øper Stone, is of a reddi≈øh colour, (and not as ≈øome ≈øay, of a green interwoven with red ≈øpots) it comes from the East-Indies.

div.head: Lapis Judaicus.
div.p: IS a longi≈øh Stone of the bigne≈øs of a Finger; ≈øome ≈øhorter, 'tis of a gray colour; tho≈øe which come from Syria are be≈øt e≈øteemed.

div.head: Lapis Lazuli.
div.p: IS a blewi≈øh Stone, of a mo≈øt excellent colour if fine, (of which Ultramarine is made) ≈øome are with Golden (or rather Bra≈øs) Veins interwoven; the cour≈øer is mixt with white, like rough Alabai≈øter; the be≈øt is that which holds its colour in Fire, and comes from the East-Indies and Turky; That which is found in Germany, is nothing near ≈øo good.

div.head: Lapis Lyncis.
div.p: IS a Stone of various colour, but mo ‚Ä¢ t betwixt a gray and brown, ≈øharp at one end like an Arrow, and Pyramid fa≈øhion, the bigne≈øs of a little Finger: They are found in Candia, Pomerania, Helvetia, and other parts of Germany.

div.head: Lapis Magnes.
div.p: LOad-≈øtone is of an Iron colour, and looks ≈øometimes ru≈øty; if good, it will draw Iron ≈øtrongly to it, by vertue of which, Sailers and Mariners find out all parts of the World: 'Tis found near Iron Mines, in Norway, Germany, Italy, Sweedland, and Cornwal here in England.

div.head: * Lapis Manateae.
div.p: LApis Manateae, is a whiti≈øh bone of a Fi≈øh called Manatea, which is plentiful in America and the We≈øt-Indies, viz. St. Chri≈øtopher's, Mevis, Jamaica, &c. It is very white and hard, like a Stone, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling white Ivory.

div.head: Lapis Nephriticus.
div.p: IS a grayi≈øh Stone, inclining to a pale green; it comes out of New and Old Spain, likewi≈øe from ≈øome parts of Germany, of which one has been ≈øeen weighing fifty Pound and more at Francf ‚Ä¢ rt.

div.head: Lapis O≈øtiocolla
div.p: IS of a whiti≈øh colour, very rough, in ≈øhape like the Pipe of a mans Bone; 'tis found in the Palatinate, Darm≈øtad, and in Saxony.

div.head: Lapis Sapphirus
div.p: IS of a Steel colour, in very ≈ømall pieces, that ≈øort comes from Germany, and is u≈øed in Phy≈øick; but the Oriental Sapphire is of a mo≈øt curious blew colour, which is ≈øet in Rings, and is brought from the Ea≈øt-Indies.

div.head: Lapis Rubinus
div.p: IS of a pure, fine, red, fiery colour; that which is Phy≈øically u≈øed, is very ≈ømall, like Gravel, but of blood red colour; the harder they are, the better they are reckoned: The ≈ømall ones which are u≈øed, come out of Germany, Bohemia and Italy; the large Oriental Rubies, being Jewels of great worth, come from Zeylon, and other parts of the East-Indies.

div.head: Lapis Sardus.
div.p: IS of a fle≈øhy colour, therefore ≈øometimes (though corruptly) Carneol; they are found in Egypt, Arabia, and likewi≈øe very good ones in Bohemia and Sile≈øia.

div.head: * Lapis Smaragdus.
div.p: EMerauld Stone, are (if good) of a very fine green and lively colour, e≈øpecially tho≈øe which are the Oriental; the other which come out of Egypt, & Germany, are far inferiour, being ≈øometimes mixt with white and purple Amethysts.

div.head: Lapis Topa≈øius.
div.p: TOpas Stones, ≈øome are very hard, and if fine and a good lu≈øtre, they re≈øemble a Diamond, the neare≈øt of any others; more ≈øoft, re≈øemble Cry≈øtals, and ≈øo are tho≈øe which are found in Bohemia; They are likewi≈øe called Chry≈øolithus.

div.head: * Lapis Tutia
div.p: IS a dark grayi≈øh Stone, very rough on the one ≈øide, and hollow and ≈ømooth on the other; 'tis ≈øaid to be the Exfulmination of Bra≈øs Mettal, but I rather believe it Natural: They are brought from the Ea≈øt Indies.

div.head: Lapis ex felle Bovis.
div.p: IS a little Stone found in the gall of an Oxe.

div.head: Lapis Spongiae.
div.p: ARe little white Stones which are found among≈øt the Sponges, being ≈øuppo≈øed to be that which fa≈øtneth the Sponges to the Rocks: They come from the Gulph L ‚Ä¢ panto.

div.head: Lapis Aetites.
div.p:
THe Eagle Stone is of two ≈øorts; the Oriental is of the bigne≈øs of a Prune, or a Plumb, of a yellowi≈øh gray colour, the other of divers ≈øhapes and bigne≈øs, are found near Sweinford in Germany. They
have another Stone within (as it were pregnant) which rattles, tho≈øe are of an Iron colour, rough without, ≈øome of them are poli≈øhed; they are found in the Ne≈øt of an Eagle. Women with Child carry them under the left Arm, about them, to hinder Mi≈øcarriage and Abortion.

div.head: Lapis Hibernus.
div.p: IRi≈øh ≈ølate, is a ≈øofti≈øh Stone which is ea≈øily ≈øcraped to a Powder; 'tis of an A≈øh-blew colour, inclining to black.

div.head: Lignum Aloes.
div.p: IS brought from Bantam, in the Ea≈øt-Indies, and is by them called Colum-back; 'tis of a mo≈øt fragrant ≈ømell, and of a darki≈øh colour; the knotty, re≈øinous, and blacke≈øt ≈øort, which is ≈øometimes full of black re≈øin, like Aloes, is to be cho≈øen.

div.head: * Lignum A≈øpalathum
div.p:
COmes likewi≈øe from the Ea≈øt-Indies in great pieces, much re≈øembling Lignum Aloes, but ≈øomewhat of a lighter
colour, but nothing near ≈øo fragrant nor good.

div.head: * Lignum Guajacum.
div.p: LIgnum Vitae, looks greeni≈øh and blewi≈øh within, and white without; 'tis very heavy, and cometh from Jamaica, and other parts of the We≈øt-Indies.

div.head: Lignum Juniperi.
div.p: JUniper Wood groweth here in England, and mo≈øt parts of Europe, 'tis very well ≈øcented, like the Berries, if cut in March.

div.head: * Lignum Lenti≈øcinum.
div.p: IS the Wood of a Ma≈øtich Tree, which cometh from Mar≈øeilles in the ≈øhapes of Faggot-≈øticks, when ra≈øp'd, it will ≈ømell a little like Mastic: The ≈ømalle≈øt ≈øprigs of all are be≈øt e≈øteemed. It groweth likewi≈øe in Italy, and great quantities in Chio.

div.head: Lignum Nephriticum.
div.p:
IS a Wood which is blew within, and white without; to know whether it
be right, is to ≈øcrape ≈øome of the inner Wood, and let it ≈øtand for four or five hours in Water, it will turn the ≈øaid Water into a blewi≈øh Tincture, which will appear above; 'tis brought from Mexico, the Spani≈øh West-Indies.

div.head: Lignum Rhodium.
div.p: 'TIs by ≈øome called Ro≈øen Wood, not that any Ro≈øes do grow upon it, but that the Wood has much the ≈øame fragrancy; the be≈øt is very fat, of a deep yellowi≈øh colour, inclining to red, is of a very ≈øtrong ≈ømell, and if broken, of an oyly ≈øub≈øtance; 'tis brought from the Canaries.

div.head: Lignum Santalum Album.
div.p: VVHite Sanders Wood is brought from the East-Indies, is of a very little ≈ømell, in long ≈øticks as big as a Leg.

div.head: Lignum Santalum Citrium.
div.p: YEllow Sanders cometh likewi≈øe from the Ea≈øt-Indies, being very fragrant, and of a ≈øweet ≈ømell.

div.head: Lignum Santalum Rubrum.
div.p: REd Sanders, is a red and heavy Wood (called in Holland, Caliatours Wood) it is brought from the Ea≈øt-Indies, and if ground, is a very fine red Powder.

div.head: Lignum Sa≈ø≈øafras.
div.p: SA≈ø≈øafras Wood, is rather a Root than Wood, of a plea≈øant ≈ømell; the be≈øt is in long Sticks, ≈øtreight, and not jumpy; the Bark without is very red, and cuts of a Fle≈øh colour within.

div.head: Lithargyrus Argenti.
div.p: LItharge of Silver is whiti≈øh, and in lumps, very heavy, ≈øhining and gli≈øtering, ea≈øily broken in ≈øhivers if good, if otherwi≈øe, 'tis hard and rocky; 'tis a made thing out of Lead: The be≈øt of it is made in Poland; that which is made in Germany is nothing near ≈øo good.

div.head: Lithargyrus Auri.
div.p:
LItharge of Gold is made like the former of Lead, being ≈ømaller than
that of Silver, of a redder colour, more re≈øembling to Gold; 'tis not improperly called the foam of Lead; there is no other difference betwixt both ≈øorts, than that the Litharge of Gold is more boyled: The be≈øt cometh from Dantzick, and is of a fine reddi≈øh colour.

div.head: Magi≈øterium Corallior.
div.p: MAgi≈øtery of Coral, is a Chymical Preparation made of red Coral and di≈øtilled Vinegar, &c. whereby the Coral is reduced into a fine Powder, almo≈øt inpalpable. Some make it in little Casks, but it is nothing the better for it.

div.head: Magi≈øterium Perlarum.
div.p: MAgi≈øtery of Pearls is likewi≈øe prepared of Pearls, as afore≈øaid.

div.head: * Margaritae Occitendal.
div.p: OCcidental Pearls, ≈øo called, becau≈øe they are not of that Oriental Lu≈øtre, brightne≈øs, nor ≈ømoothne≈øs, as the Oriental Pearls; They come from Surrat and the coa≈øt of the Ea≈øt-Indies, being a Seed Pearl which is more ob≈øcure or muddy than the Oriental; the be≈øt are round, even, of a ≈øhining Lu≈øtre: There is a large ≈øcrubbed, and rough ≈øort, which are the lea≈øt e≈øteemed.

div.head: Margaritae Orientales.
div.p: ORiental Pearls, the be≈øt are of a fine lu≈øtrous oriental Water, of an even ≈øize, round and ≈ømooth, ≈øomething harder than the Occidental ≈øort; They come from the East-Indies, as afore≈øaid, the be≈øt from Per≈øia. There is another ≈øort called the South-Sea Pearls, they are very ≈ømooth, of a more whiter and paler colour.

div.head: Margaritae Scotiae.
div.p:
SCotch Pearls are pretty good, ‚Ä¢ ound, ≈ømooth and even, but very hard,
not ea≈øily beaten into a Powder, not ≈øo lu≈øtrous, but more of a Copper and Leadi≈øh dull colour, than any of the afore≈øaid: They come from Scotland, Chester and Wales.

div.head: Manna.
div.p: IS a Dew falling out of the Air, upon the Branches and Twigs of Trees, upon Herbs and Stones, and there it hardneth; the large, bright, and flaky ≈øort, dry and whiti≈øh, very little inclining to a yellow, is be≈øt e≈øteemed.: This is found and gathered in Syria, Per≈øia, Calabria; and though ≈øome have e≈øteemed that of Syria be≈øt, yet the Calabrian is with us mo≈øt preferred.

div.head: Mater Perlarum.
div.p: MOther of Pearls; the be≈øt cometh from the East-Indies in large ≈øhells, the nearer it re≈øembleth Pearls, and being in large ≈ømooth ≈øhells, the better: There is ≈øome found in Jar≈øey and Guern≈øey, full of Holes, ≈øcruffy without, but they are of little value.

div.head: Mandibula Lucii.
div.p: THe Jaw-bones of a Pike, are long and white, the Teeth as ≈øharp as Needles, are found here in England, and all parts of Europe.

div.head: Mastich.
div.p: IS a ≈ømall Gum which cometh from the ≈øame Tree, out of which we have the Chio Turpentine, and therefore by many called Oyl of Ma≈øtich, growing in Egypt, Syria, and other parts of Turky, as al≈øo the I≈øle of Chio: The be≈øt Mastich is of a light colour, almo≈øt tran≈øparent, free from Dro≈øs: It is brought to us from Smyrna and Aleppo.

div.head: Mel Anglicanum.
div.p: ENgli≈øh Honey is the product of Bees, of a pale yellow colour, of a lively ≈ømell and ta≈øte, of a good body, not grea≈øie, the (white) Virgins Honey is accounted the be≈øt; the yellow is inferiour to the white Honey, is gathered in all parts of Europe, A≈øia and Affrica.

div.head: Mercurius Dulcis.
div.p: IS a Chymical Preparation by way of Sublimation of Quick-Silver and Mercury corro≈øive, &c. If duly ≈øublimed it will be very white and clear, the in≈øide ≈øharp, and longi≈øh like Needles, and of a ≈øweet ta≈øt.

div.head: Mercurius Sublimatus.
div.p: SUblimate is al≈øo a Chymical Preparation, the be≈øt, very white and ≈øhining, &c. and comes from Venice in large Cakes, which are better than any made el≈øewhere.

div.head: Mercurius Praecipitatus.
div.p: MErcury Praecipitate is likewi≈øe Chymically prepared of Quick-Silver, &c. The be≈øt is heavy, of a very lively fine, red and gli≈øtering, even beyond Vermilion: The be≈øt cometh from Venice, that which is made here and in Holland, is not ≈øo good.

div.head: Mercurius Vitae.
div.p: IS a Chymical Preparation, made out of Quick Silver, Antimony, &c.

div.head: * Myrobalani Bellerici.
div.p: IS a round Mirabolane: They are much like ≈øome Gauls, of a yellowi≈øh colour.

div.head: * Myrobalani Chebuli.
div.p: MYrobalani Chebuli, are the large≈øt of Myrabolanes, of a yellowi≈øh colour, and a long ≈øize, well filled and large.

div.head: * Myrobalani Citrinae.
div.p: ARE much like the afore≈øaid Chebuli, but a great deal le≈øs and ≈ømaller, longi≈øh, and of a yellowi≈øh colour. All Myrobalanes come from Surrat in the East-Indies.

div.head: * Mirabolanes Emblici.
div.p: THe≈øe Myrobalanes are of a blacki≈øh colour, growing naturally in ≈øeveral pieces, as if they were ≈øliced or cut ≈øo.

div.head: * Myrobalani Indae.
div.p: THough all Myrobalanes come from the East-Indies, yet there is one ≈øort which is called by the name Indian Myrobalan, being very ≈ømall, and almo≈øt eight cornered, of a black colour.

div.head: * Mo≈øchus.
div.p:
MUsk is an Excremental Excre≈øcence, or a ≈øwelling of corrupted blood, about the Navle of a Musk Goat or Buck, (and not a Cat) which after Putrefaction and Ripening, turns to Musk in a perfect Cod, which is ≈øaid falls off of the Creature: The be≈øt is the Tonquin or China Musk, in thin Cods, well filled, round, and with little ≈øhort Hairs, the Musk within of a good lively Musk colour, very ≈øtrong, ≈øweet ≈ømell, ≈øomething moi≈øt, of a ≈øtrong ta≈øt, a little bitteri≈øh. The Agria and Bengale Musk, is in thick Cods, long hair'd, a great deal of skin, and not half ≈øo full of Musk as the former; the Musk neither ≈øo good nor fragrant. The Ru≈ø≈øia Musk is wor≈øe than any, being cour≈øe, of a dark colour, great Tare and little Musk: Tho≈øe Musk Cods which
have been opened and ≈øowed again, are very ≈øu≈øpicious of adulteration; for there is often found Lead, Stones, Leather, &c. ≈øtuffed in the Cods, among≈øt the Musk, and that ≈øo cunningly, that it can hardly be perceived.

div.head: Mumia.
div.p: THe Arabian Mumia, is a Liquor ≈øweating out of dead Bodies, being Imbalmed with Aloes, Myrrh and Bal≈øom, &c. wrapped up in Cere-cloths: Sometimes whole Bodies may be ≈øeen, with Hands, Legs and Toes, perfectly intire, being of a black colour: And that Mumia which is mo≈øt gummy or bituminous, is be≈øt e≈øteemed. 'Tis brought from Chio and Egypt.

div.head: Nuces √® Barbadoes.
div.p:
BArbadoes Nuts, is nothing el≈øe but a large Cartaputia, which provokes Vomit vehemently, and ≈øometimes works by Stool; ≈øome are of a blacki≈øh Husk,
≈øome ≈øpeckled, they are larger than a French Bean, and have a very white Kernel within.

div.head: Nuces de Ben.
div.p: BEN Nuts, is of the bigne≈øs of a round large Ha≈øel Nut, of a grayi≈øh Husk, a white Oleaginous Kernel within, out of which Oyl is drawn, like as out of Almonds They are brought from Turkey, viz. Smyrna and Aleppo.

div.head: * Nuces Cupru≈ø≈øi.
div.p: CYpre≈øs Nuts are of a longi≈øh ≈øhape, ≈øomething re≈øembling tho≈øe of a Firtree, being more clo≈øe and not ≈øo open. They are gathered here in England and other parts of Europe, &c.

div.head: * Nuces Pi≈øtaechiae.
div.p:
PI≈øtachies is a little ≈ømall longi≈øh Nut, the Kernel within, if fre≈øh, is very Red, and the out≈øide and the in≈øide very Green, of a mo≈øt plea≈øant ta≈øte; the hard Shell is very White and Greeni≈øh, inclining to a Red, with a Husk over it. They grow in Per≈øia, Arabia, Syria, and are
brought from Aleppo and Smyrna in Turkey.

div.head: * Nuces Vomicae.
div.p: TIS a flat round Nut, almo≈øt as big as a Leaden Half-penny, a little hollow in the middle, which is brought from the Ea≈øt-Indies. It will infatuate any flying Foul or Bird, as likewi≈øe ≈øome other Creatures, &c.

div.head: * Nuces Indicae.
div.p: THIS Nut is in ≈øhape like a Nutmeg, in chawing turns Red; 'tis ≈øaid they will make one Drunk in taking them inwardly, but I could never find it. The People in the Ea≈øt-Indies chawing them for Refre≈øhment or Recreation, as we do Tobacco.

div.head: Nuclei Pinei.
div.p: PINE Kernel, is a black and longi≈øh Kernel, ≈øomething le≈øs than a Bayberry, and a very white Kernel, Oily like an Almond within. They come from France by the way of Mar≈øeilles.

div.head: * Nuces Mo≈øchatae.
div.p:
THE Nutmeg is a Fruit of two kinds, the Ma≈øculine (a long and large Nut ≈øeldom u≈øed) the Foeminine a round and le≈ø≈øer Nut, which are laid in quick Lime, that the Worms ≈øhould not take them. The be≈øt are new of a fati≈øh ≈øub≈øtance, of a full roundne≈øs and heavyne≈øs, not lean nor ≈øcraggy, of a grateful ta≈øte, and not hollow within; they are carried from an I≈øland called Band ‚Ä¢
to Batava, and from thence, as well as all other Spices, brought to Holland, and from thence they are imported by the King's Licen≈øe: And ≈øo is Mace, Cloves, and Cinnamon, &c.

div.head: Oculi Cancrorum.
div.p:
CRabs Eyes, (improperly ≈øo called, for they have none) but cray Fi≈øh Eyes (in the German Crebtz) of which there is ≈øome of a large bigne≈øs, as big as the
Che≈øter Lob≈øters, which have every one two Stones, or Crabs Eyes in the fore part of the Head, even beyond their Eyes. In Sile≈øia they have va≈øt quantities, in≈øomuch, that the Servants do condition but to eat ≈øo many times in a Week: There are ≈øtore of Cray Fi≈øh likewi≈øe in Poland. They are brought from Dantzick, Hamburgh, and other Sea Ports of Germany.

div.head: Oleum Ab≈øinthii.
div.p: OYL of Wormword is a Chymical Di≈øtillation, per Alembicum, of the ≈øame Herb; the Oyl of it is of a very dark colour, ≈ømelling ≈øtrong of Wormwood; very hot, and pretty heavy, ≈øinking under Water half way.

div.head: Oleum Ani≈øi.
div.p: IS drawn from Anni≈øeed in Germany. The be≈øt is very white, congealed like a hard Snow, ≈ømelling ≈øtrong of the Anni≈øeed.

div.head: Oleum Amygdalarum Amar.
div.p:
OYL of bitter Almonds, is drawn by a ≈øtrong Screw-Pre≈øs from bitter
Almonds. The Oyl is neverthele≈øs ≈øweet; the be≈øt is when new and clear.

div.head: Oleum Amygdalarum Dulc.
div.p: IS drawn from ≈øweet Almonds, as the Oyl afore≈øaid.

div.head: Oleum A≈øparis.
div.p: IS an Oyl drawn from a Bird, called A≈øper, who≈øe ≈øcent is ≈øaid to be ≈øo ≈øtrong, that Fi≈øhes are drawn by the ≈øcent as he is flying over the River, and ≈øo taken up by him, having one leg like a Hawk, the other like a Duck.

div.head: Oleum Auranti ‚Ä¢ rum.
div.p: OYL of Oranges, is drawn from the upper rind, or Peel of Sevil Oranges, by a Chymical way, per Alembicum. The be≈øt is of a mo≈øt pure, fragrant ≈ømell, like the be≈øt Sevil Oranges.

div.head: Oleum de Ben.
div.p:
OYL of Ben is made by Expre≈ø≈øion, out of the inner Kernel of a Ben Nut. The Oyl is more of conden≈øed
Body, and will keep longer than any Oyl of Almonds.

div.head: Oleum Carvi.
