div.p: IS an Oyl of Carvi Seeds, drawn from tho≈øe Seeds by Di≈øtillation. 'Tis very hot in ta≈øt, ≈ømells ≈øtrong of the Seeds.

div.head: Oleum Cymini.
div.p: OYL of Cumin Seeds, is drawn as afore≈øaid, ≈ømelling and ta≈øting of the ≈øaid Seeds.

div.head:
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ amomi.
div.p:
OYL of „Äà‚óä„Äâ , is the mo≈øt curious and be „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ ll Oyls, Chymically drawn. The „Äà‚óä„Äâ is made in the Ea≈øt-Indies, of a mo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ fragrant ≈ømell, yellowi≈øh colour, hot and biting, like Fire in the ta≈øt; very heavy and ponderous, ≈øinking under Water to the very bottom.

div.head: Oleum Caryophyllorum.
div.p:
OYL of Cloves is likewi≈øe a very odoriferous heavy Oyl, prepared as above≈øaid, of a fragrant ≈ømell, like Cloves,
of a pale reddi≈øh colour, and ≈øo heavy, that it runs under Water.

div.head: Oleum √® Cortice Caryophyllorum.
div.p: IS drawn from Clove Bark, as the Oyl afore≈øaid; but nothing near ≈øo good, nor odoriferous, nor heavy, as that of Cloves, and of the ≈øame colour, but a little darker.

div.head: Oleum Cerae.
div.p: IS an Oyl Chymically extracted, by Retort. &c.

div.head: Oleum Faeniculi Dulcis.
div.p: OYL of ≈øweet Fennel-≈øeeds, is Chymically drawn from ≈øweet Fennel-≈øeeds; of a ≈øtrong ≈ømell like it; and in Winter and cold Weather, it will conden≈øe like the Oyl of Anni≈øeeds.

div.head: Oleum Guajaci.
div.p: IS an Oyl Chymically drawn from Lignum Vitae Chips, by Retort; of a ≈øtrong foetid ≈ømell, of a thick and black Body.

div.head: Oleum Ja≈ø≈øemini.
div.p:
IS drawn by Gentlewomen from Ja≈ø≈øemin Flowers, b ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ve ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eration of the Sun; 'tis of a mo≈ø ‚Ä¢ fragrant ≈ømell. The be≈øt comes from Italy, and ≈øome from France.

div.head: Oleum Junip ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
div.p:
IS drawn from new Junip ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ erries, by Alembick: The Oyl „Äà‚óä„Äâ clear, of a ≈øweet ≈ømell, re≈øembling the Berries.

div.head: Oleum Latericium.
div.p: OR Oleum Philo≈øophorum, is drawn from Brick-batts, Chymically by Retort.

div.head: Oleum Laurinum Com.
div.p: IS made of Bay-leaves, and Sallad-oyl, &c.

div.head: Oleum Laurinum Fland.
div.p: IS a green Oyl, very thick and green; made of green Bay-berries, and Bayleaves. 'Tis brought from Italy.

div.head: Oleum Macis per expre≈øs.
div.p: OYL of Mace, by expre≈ø≈øion, ≈øo called here in England; is nothing el≈øe but Oyl of Nutmegs by expre≈ø≈øion; the be≈øt comes from the Ea≈øt-Indies: In China jarrs; of a thick Body, a pale Orange colour. There is another ≈øort brought from Holland in four ≈øquare Cakes, but nothing near ≈øo good as the former.

The true Oyl of Mace, by expre≈ø≈øion, is made in the Ea≈øt-Indies, out of fre≈øh Mace, and cometh over in Gla≈ø≈øes and Bottles, being a liquid reddi≈øh Oyl, ≈ømelling very ≈øtrong of the Mace; (and a little ≈øowri≈øh) at the bottom a little thicker than above.

div.head: Oleum Macis Com.
div.p: IS a made ≈øtuff of Sheeps tallow. Palm Oyl, and ≈øuch like ≈øtuff coloured, and a little grea≈øed over with Oyl of Nutmegs, &c. is of little value, and le≈øs virtue than the afore≈øaid.

div.head: Oleum Majorani.
div.p: OYL of ≈øweet Marjoram, is of a very clear colour, a very little inclining to a red ca≈øt, fragrant ≈ømell, drawn by Alembick, the Herb being dried fir≈øt.

div.head: Oleum Menthae.
div.p: OYL of Mint, is drawn as the former, of a fragrant ≈ømell, re≈øembling the Herb.

div.head: Oleum Nervinum.
div.p: NErve Oyl, is a made thing here by ≈øome particular People, &c.

div.head: Oleum Nucis Mo≈øchatae
div.p: OYL of Nutmegs, is drawn by Alembick, from Nutmegs; is of a clear Oyl, like Water, of a fragrant ≈ømell, and hot, grave ta≈øt like Nutmegs.

div.head: Oleum Origani.
div.p:
IS drawn from Origanum, by Di≈øtillation, and ≈øometimes off wild Time; of
a dark red Colour, of a ≈øtrong ≈øcent, a very ≈øharp and hot-biting ta≈øt, &c.

div.head: Oleum Palmae.
div.p: IS the product of the Palm-Tree in Guinny, from whence it is brought, of a red, or rather a deep Orange Colour, of a ≈øweet ≈ømell; that which is turned White, and Pale Yellowi≈øh, is decayed.

div.head: Oleum Petroleum.
div.p: IS a fat Liquor, flowing from Rocks, and other Stones in Italy and Sicily: There are two ≈øorts, the white comes from Parma, the red from Sicily and Italy, &c.

div.head: Oleum Rori≈ømarini.
div.p: IS an Oyl drawn from Ro≈øemary, by Alembick, is very clear like Water, and of a ≈øweet ≈ømell like Ro≈øemary.

div.head: Oleum Scorpionum.
div.p: IS made with Oyl of Almonds, and live Scorpions put into it.

div.head: Oleum Spicae.
div.p: IS an Oyl drawn from Lavender, Ro≈øemary, and other Herbs in France, as they grow together in the Fields, of a ≈øtrong Smell and clear Colour; it comes from Mar≈øeilles in France.

div.head: Oleum Sabinae.
div.p: OYL of Savine is a Oyl Chymically drawn from the Herb (or rather Shrub) of Sabina, by Di≈øtilling in it in Water by Alembick, the Oyl being very clear, ≈ømelling very ≈øtrong of the ≈øaid Herb; the Oyl being often imported from Franconia in Germany, wh ‚Ä¢ re quantities of the ≈øaid Savine doth grow.

div.head: Oleum Succini
div.p: OYL of Amber is Chymically prepared, by retort out of cour≈øe Amber, being rectified 'tis of a light Amber Colour, of a ≈øtrong ≈ømell; the fir≈øt drawing, is a foetid thick Oyl, of a dark Colour.

div.head: Ol ‚Ä¢ um Sulphuris Com.
div.p: OYL of Sulphur is Chymically drawn from Brim≈øtone, of a clear Colour, a clear and acid ta≈øte, and in effect, Spirit of Vitriol is every whit as good.

div.head: Oleum Sulphuris per Campan.
div.p: IS Chymically drawn from Brim≈øtone, the ≈øame being ≈øet on fire under a great Gla≈øs Bell, and gathered in a large Bladder; 'tis of a clear Colour, ≈øomething inclining to a yellowi≈øh Colour, of a very acid ta≈øte, and pretty heavy, almo≈øt without ≈ømell.

div.head: Oleum Sa≈ø≈øafrae.
div.p: IS drawn from Sa≈ø≈øafra≈øs-wood, per Alembicum; 'tis of a reddi≈øh Colour, very hot and heavy, and will ≈øink under water.

div.head: Oleum Tart ‚Ä¢ ri Com:
div.p: IS a mixt Oyl of Ol. Tartari, per deliquium and Water.

div.head: Oleum Tartari.
div.p: IS an Oyl made of calcined Tartar, hung in an Hipocratical Sleeve, in a Celler which runs out per deliquium, in a heavy but clear Liquor, ≈øome-what ≈øharp and hot in ta≈øte.

div.head: Oleum Thymi.
div.p: OYL of Tyme is drawn from that Herb per Alembicum; of a yellowi≈øh clear Colour, fragrant ≈ømell and hot ta≈øt ‚Ä¢

div.head: ebinthinae.
div.p: OYL of Turpentine is drawn out of common Turpentine, which comes out of France; 'tis of a clear Body, very hot, penetrating, and of a ≈øtrong ≈ømell.

div.head: Oleum Vitrioli.
div.p:
IS an Oyl drawn from calcined Copperas, by a ≈øtrong Reverberatory Fire, when it is rectified 'tis very clear, of a very heavy Oleaginous Body, very hot,
burning a Pack-Thread to pieces in an in≈øtant.

div.head: Oleum Myrrhae.
div.p: IS Chymically drawn out of Myrrhae per Retort; 'tis very thick, and of a ≈øtrong ≈ømell.

div.head: Opium.
div.p: IS made out of Poppies, being a J ‚Ä¢ ice boyled up to a Conden≈øity, ≈øme ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ng very ≈øtrong, of a good lively Colour, cutting ea≈øily, not hard, being wrapped up in Leaves; the be≈øt cometh from Aleppo, and Smyrna in Turky; 'tis brought from Surrat and Per≈øia, in the Ea≈øt-Indi ‚Ä¢ s; but is far inferiour in quality, being nothing near ≈øo clean, nor of ≈øo ≈øtrong a ≈ømell, as the Turky ≈øort.

div.head: Opobal≈øamum.
div.p: SEE Bal≈øam Judaicum, Bal≈øam Gilead, &c. being nothing el≈øe.

div.head: Os Sepiae.
div.p: CUttle-bones, is called by the Germans, the Scum of the Seas, being in effect, nothing el≈øe but a White Scummy Sub≈øtance, and the≈øe are found here in England in Su≈ø≈øex, and near the I≈øle of Wight, and other parts on the Sea‚ñ™≈øhoar, tho≈øe which are large, long, broad, and well dryed, are be≈øt, they are much ≈øold by the≈øe Ironmongers, which ≈øell Tools to Silver-Smiths and Gold-Smiths.

div.head: Os de Corde Cervi.
div.p: THE Bone out of the Heart of a Stag, is a Bone found in the Hearts of Stags, almo≈øt re≈øembling a Cro≈øs, but ≈øome more than others, being a little flat bone, and to be had in any part of Europe, e≈øpecially, if they u≈øe tho≈øe of an Ox in≈øtead of it.

div.head: Piper Album.
div.p: WHite Pepper, is made from the large≈øt black Pepper, by art; being very full, round, large and white. Some has been made here in England, but not ≈øo good.

div.head: Piper Guineae.
div.p: GUinea Pepper, is improperly ≈øo called, not any coming from thence, but from Mar≈øeilles: That which is in lively red Cods, not broken, and fre≈øh, is to be preferred.

div.head: Piper longum.
div.p: LOng Pepper, cometh to us from the Ea≈øt-Indies: The larger, and white within, bright without, is the be≈øt.

div.head: Piper Nigrum.
div.p: BLack Pepper, is more of u≈øe to Grocers and Druggi≈øts. The be≈øt and large≈øt, is your Malabar Pepper, being heavy, and of a good ≈øub≈øtance.

div.head: Pix Burgundica.
div.p: BUrgundy Pitch, comes from a certain kind of Firr-tree, near Strasbourgh: That which is ≈øoft, and of a bright colour, is be≈øt.

div.head: Pix Liquida.
div.p: SOft Pitch, is a made thing by the Shoomakers, and of little u≈øe among≈øt the Druggi≈øts.

div.head: Pix Navalis.
div.p: IS a ≈øofti≈øh Pitch, which cometh from Godenburgh, and other places of Sweeden; having its name (Ship-Pitch) becau≈øe great quantities are u≈øed in building of Ships.

div.head: Pix Sicca.
div.p: IS the very ≈øame as Ship Pitch, as afore≈øaid, being only boyled to a dryne≈øs or hardne≈øs; and therefore called dry Pitch, becau≈øe the other is liquid and running.

div.head: Plumbum Album.
div.p: SEE Ceru≈ø≈øa, both being one and the ≈øame; except ≈øome that are papered over, others are not; which go by the Name of white Lead.

div.head: Plumbum Nigrum.
div.p: THE be≈øt black Lead is found here in England, in black Lead Mines; ≈øoft, and of a firm body, not rocky, ≈ømooth, in pieces of ≈øeveral bigne≈øs. There comes a ≈øort from Spain, and although it be ≈øoft, yet 'tis ≈øubject to be brittle, and break in ≈ømall pieces, and Powder, that nothing can be made out of it. Another ≈øort coming from the We≈øt-Ind ‚Ä¢ es, is cour≈øer and rocky, of little u≈øe and value.

div.head: Plumbum Rubrum.
div.p: RED Lead is made here in England, in Darby≈øhire, in great quantities; and from thence Tran≈øported to mo≈øt parts of Europe; being of a red colour, the next to Vermilion, of a heavy body.

div.head: Plumbum U≈øtum.
div.p: IS a Chymical Preparation (which is called Caementatoria) of Lead, which is made with Powder of Brim≈øtone, and the Scales of Lead, which being thus burned, is often wa≈øhed; and thus becomes the Plumbum U≈øtum, which is u≈øed.

div.head: Polium Montanum.
div.p: IS an Herb which groweth in Sicily, Italy, and Spain, being covered over with a downe of a lively fre≈øh ≈ømell, and greeni≈øh Colour.

div.head: Pompholyx,
div.p:
OR Nihil Album, having its name from its fine and pure white Colour; 'tis ≈øaid to be gathered of a Fume which
ri≈øes from Metal (in the fu≈øion of it) being white and fine, but nothing near ≈øo heavyas white Lead. It is brought out of Germany.

div.head: Priapus Cervi.
div.p: IS the Pi≈øle of a Hart or Stag dry'dup, of a reddi≈øh brown Colour.

div.head: Priapus Equi Marini.
div.p: A Sea-hor≈øe Pi≈øle is of a bony ≈øub≈øtance like Ivory, ≈øome above half a yard in length, thick at the fore part (or Glans) and running ≈ømaller at the hind part. They are brought from Greenland, and other parts of the We≈øt-Indies.

div.head: Priapus Tauri.
div.p: 'TIS the Pi≈øle of a Bull, almo≈øt a yard long, dryed up in the Sun.

div.head: Priapus Turturis Marini.
div.p: 'TIS the Pi≈øle of a Sea Turtel, dryed up, is a quarter of a yard long.

div.head: Pulmo Vulpis.
div.p: 'TIS the Lungs of a Fox dryed, of a ≈øtrong ≈ømell; the newe≈øt, fre≈øhe≈øt and ≈øounde≈øt are to be preferred.

div.head: Pulvis Curcumae.
div.p: POwder of Turmerick is ground in a Mill, of a fine lively reddi≈øh Orange Colour; being free from all other mixtures, ≈ømelling ≈øtrong of Cucurma.

div.head: Pulvis Enulae Campan.
div.p: ELecampane Powder, is ground as afore≈øaid, the Roots being well dryed fir≈øt; of a good ≈ømell, re≈øembling Elecampane.

div.head: Pulvis Glycyrrhizae.
div.p: LIquori≈øh Powder, is grounded out of Spani≈øh Liquori≈øh, of a pale yellowi≈øh Colour, and a ≈øtrong ta≈øte of the Liquori≈øh, 'tis adulterated with Flower, whichmay be di≈øtingui≈øhed in the ta≈øt, &c.

div.head: Pulvis Santali Rubri.
div.p: POwder of red Sanders, is ground by a Mill, of a fine lively red colour. 'Tis u≈øed therefore, more in Dying than Phy≈øical U≈øes.

div.head: Radix Acori.
div.p: OF which the true≈øt is reckoned to be the Calamus Aromaticus; but among≈øt us here in England it is a Root which comes from the Ea≈øt-Indies, much re≈øembling Galanga major, being larger, more dark of colour without, and whiter within; not ≈øo Aromatick, or fragrant in ta≈øt, as Galanga minor.

div.head: Radix Alcannae.
div.p:
ALkanet Root, is of a dark red colour, and white within; that which is ≈øo the mo≈øt part red, very thin, and not woody, is be≈øt e≈øteemed. They
are brought out of France, Italy, and ≈øome out of Holland.

div.head: Radix Angelicae.
div.p: ANgelica Root, is a longi≈øh Root, a large thick Head; a great many ≈ømall Roots (or large and long Vipers) of above half a foot in length, of a good odoriferous ≈ømell, a hot Aromatick ta≈øt; the Root is flexible (if new) breaks white within. They are ≈øometimes mixt with Meum Roots, which break of a brown yellowi≈øh within. They come from Germany.

div.head: Radix Ari≈øtolochiae Long.
div.p: LOng Ari≈øtolochia Roots come to us out of France by the way of Mar≈øcilles; being a long thicki≈øh Root, cuts white, a little inclining to a yellowi≈øh colour within. Tho≈øe which are fre≈øh, are to be preferred.

div.head: Radix Ari≈øtolochiae Rotundae.
div.p:
ROund Ari≈øtolochia Roots, are of a round ≈øhape, much like the fore≈øaid
Roots; coming likewi≈øe the ≈øame way, &c.

div.head: Radix A≈øari.
div.p: ASarum Root, is a ≈ømall (A≈øh-coloured) Root, long fibers; of a pretty ≈ømell, and aromatick and hot ta≈øt. They are likewi≈øe brought from Germany.

div.head: Radix Behen Albi.
div.p: IS a longi≈øh whiti≈øh Root, not unlike to wild Par≈ønips, but thinner. It groweth in Italy, Germany, and France, &c.

div.head: Radix Behen Rubri.
div.p: IS a dark reddi≈øh, brown coloured Root; in round rowles or ≈ølices, like Jallop: It grows as above.

div.head: Radix Bi≈øtortae.
div.p: SO called from its crooked bending together; it is likewi≈øe called the larger Snake Weed, of a whiti≈øh colour when ≈øcraped: It grows here in England and Germany, &c.

div.head: Radix Calami Aromatici.
div.p: 'TIs a ≈øweet ≈øcented Root, fragrant, hot, and ≈øomewhat bitteri≈øh in ta≈øt; it breaks white, and is a little knotty as it were. It is brought in Quantities from Germany.

div.head: * Radix Chinae Optimae.
div.p: CHina Roots, the be≈øt being large, well fed, and firm; cut white and bright within, and light brown without; free from Worms. They come from Rantam and China, in the Ea≈øt-Indies.

div.head: * Radix Chinae Nodo≈øae.
div.p: FLinty China Roots are heavy, and not ea≈øily to be broken or cut, becau≈øe of a re≈øiny flinty Sub≈øtance, which is black, like that of re≈øiny Jallop.

div.head: * Radix Contrayervae.
div.p:
COntrayerva Roots are of a lively yellowi≈øh colour, inclining to red; of an inch long, or more, full of little ≈ømall Vipers round about them; of a good plea≈øant
≈ømell, and white within. They come from the Spani≈øh We≈øt-Indies.

div.head: * Radix Co≈øti Amari.
div.p: IN the Apothecaries Shops, there is ≈øweet and bitter Co≈øtus, being both of one Species; the newe≈øt being ≈øweet, and with Age grow bitter. That which is to be cho≈øen, ought to be of an A≈øh colour without, and white within, being fre≈øh, of a firm body and well ≈øcented.

div.head: * Radix Co≈øti Dulcis.
div.p: AS what we have ≈øaid to Co≈øtus Amarus, it is the newe≈øt and fre≈øhe≈øt of Co≈øtus, &c.

div.head: * Radix Curcumae.
div.p:
TUrmerick, Terra merita, is a Root which is brought from the Ea≈øt Indies. There are two ≈øorts; one long, which is pure and fine, called the Per≈øian ≈øort; breaks not only of a fine yellow, but gives al≈øo a Tincture like Saffron: The other ≈øort is ≈øhorter and rounder, of a yellow green without‚ñ™ That which
is firm, of a lively colour in breaking, and looks not black, is the be≈øt.

div.head: * Radix Cyperi Longi.
div.p: IS a long, dark, reddi≈øh Root, full of little knots or ≈øpecks; breaking white within, of a plea≈øant ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ell; 'tis u≈øed in Perfumes, ≈øweet Powder, &c. It groweth here in England.

div.head: Radix Cyperi Rotund.
div.p: IS a round reddi≈øh Root, coming from Turky, out of Syria, Italy, and Alexandria; 'tis e≈øteemed better for vertue than the long Cypre≈øs Roots. That which is well fed, firm, and hard to be broken, of a plea≈øant acriminous ≈ømell, is to be preferred.

div.head: Radix Dictamni Alb.
div.p: IS a thin whiti≈øh Root, of a bitteri≈øh and glutenous ta≈øt. The be≈øt is gathered in Winter, and cometh to us from Germany.

div.head: Radix Doronici Rom.
div.p: DOronicum, is (a kind of a Wolf-Bane) a little ≈ømall knobby Root, firm, light, brown without, and white within. 'Tis brought from Germany; it groweth in Au≈øtria, Styria and Helvetia.

div.head: Radix Ellebori Alb.
div.p: WHite Hellebore (or Snee≈øe Root) is a round, ≈øhort, knobby Root. It comes from Germany; a little of it being ≈øcraped in Powder, will cau≈øe a violent ≈ønee≈øing.

div.head: Radix Ellebori Nigri.
div.p: BLack Hellebore, is a ≈ømall, black, viperous Root; breaketh (if good) white within. 'Tis brought in bundles from Germany.

div.head: Radix Enulae Campanae.
div.p: ELecampane Roots, grow here in England, Germany, and other parts in Europe; of a bitteri≈øh ta≈øt, and a pale yellowi≈øh colour, inclining to white.

div.head: Radix Eryngii.
div.p: ERingo Roots, Sea-holm, or Sea-holly‚ñ™ Roots, a great deal of them are brought from France. It groweth likewi≈øe in Germany, England, and other places in Europe; 'tis pre≈øerved in Confects, which are very white and delicious.

div.head: Radix Galangae.
div.p: GAlanga Minor, cometh from the Ea≈øt-Indies. 'Tis cut in little pieces, a browni≈øh red Coat, and pale red within, of a hot aromatick ta≈øt and ≈ømell.

div.head: Radix Gentianae.
div.p: GEntian Roots, is of a bitter ta≈øte, a dark yellow colour within; of a large bigne≈øs, (not ≈ølit, which is looked upon the wor≈øt) well fed, firm, breaking clear and bright within. It cometh out of Germany in great Quantities.

div.head: Radix Glycyrrhizae Angl.
div.p:
ENgli≈øh Liquorish, groweth here about this City, and in York≈øhire plentifully;
being good, 'tis large, thick, well fed, cuts bright within, and is of a good length. It groweth in mo≈øt parts of Europe.

div.head: Radix Glycyrrhizae Hi≈øpan.
div.p: SPani≈øh Liquori≈øh, is brought over to us; being dry, of a bright colour within, and not blacki≈øh.

div.head: Radix Hermodactyli.
div.p: 'TIs a Root of the bigne≈øs of a Che≈ønut, white without, and within: They are cho≈øen large, heavy, firm, not Worm eaten; being beaten, will reduce into a Powder, like Flower, of a ≈øweet ta≈øt. They come from Syria, and ≈øome parts of Italy.

div.head: * Radix Jalappae.
div.p: JAllop, is a Root which cometh from the Spani≈øh We≈øt-Indies, being cut in ≈ølices, and dryed; of which are two ≈øorts, white and black; of which, the black being re≈øinous, is to be preferred: The larger and the heavier, the better; the white is not ≈øo good, e≈øpecially Wormeaten.

div.head: Radix Iridis Florent.
div.p: FLorentine Orris, cometh from Italy; the be≈øt being very white, full, round, of a ≈øtrong fragrant ≈ømell, like Violets.

div.head: Radix Mechoacannae.
div.p: MEcoacan Roots, is a Root which cometh from the Spani≈øh We≈øt-Indies; being very white, ≈øhrinking a little. 'Tis in pieces a great deal larger than Jallop.

div.head: Radix Mei Athamant.
div.p: MEum Roots; the be≈øt groweth in Germany; is a ≈øingle Root, bearded at the Head, of a fragrant ≈ømell: Tho≈øe which are gathered here in England, are full bearded, and the Root not ≈øo large.

div.head: Radix Peoniae Maris.
div.p:
THE greater Piony, or the Male Piony, is a reddi≈øh Root, round and ‚Ä¢ hick, of no great Con≈øumption to the Druggi≈øt, being a thing very ≈øeldom u≈øed.
They grow in England, and mo≈øt parts.

div.head: Radix Phu Majoris.
div.p: PHU the great, cometh from Germany; 'tis by ≈øome called Garden Valerian: It groweth likewi≈øe in England.

div.head: Radix Polypodii Querc.
div.p: POlypody, is called by ≈øome, many Feet, or Fern; that of the Oak (being an Excre≈øcence) is the be≈øt. 'Tis found in England, Germany, &c. That which breaks green within, and dark coloured without, is be≈øt.

div.head: Radix Pyrethri.
div.p: PEllitory of Spain, is a very hot Root, breaks whiti≈øh within: That which comes from Italy and the Straits, is thicker and ≈øhorter than that which cometh out of Germany, where it is called Tooth-Root.

div.head: * Radix Rhabarbari.
div.p: THE be≈øt of all Rubarbs is brought to us from Turky; ('tis ≈øaid to grow in Tartary) of fine midling pieces, ≈ømooth, and not cru≈øty, fre≈øh coloured, a lively ≈øtrong ≈ømell, cutting firm; (in chawing ≈øomewhat bitteri≈øh, and a≈øtringent in ta≈øt) of a fre≈øh yellowi≈øh colour, a fragrant Flavour; not too heavy, nor cru≈øty, nor hollow, or rotten within. The Ru≈ø≈øia Rubarb is the next to it, which is generally large and heavy, and more cru≈øty; though ≈øometimes very fre≈øh, and well ≈øcented, but nothing near ≈øo fine as there came lately from the Ea≈øt-Indies: And though it be never ≈øo good in the Country, yet in the bringing over, it lo≈øeth its ≈ømell and goodne≈øs, by the extream Heat of the Sun, turning black and hard within, which is of little value.

div.head: * Radix Rapontici.
div.p: RAponticum cometh from Ru≈ø≈øia, as al≈øo from the Straits; that which is of a fre≈øh colour, inclining to yellow and red, is the be≈øt, and the nearer it cometh to Rubarb.

div.head: Radix Rubiae Tinctorum.
div.p: MAdder Roots are made here in England, at Wi≈øbitch, in the I≈øle of Ely, and a great deal in Zealand. The large≈øt and bigge≈øt, are preferred, being of a good reddi≈øh colour.

div.head: * Radix Sar≈øaparillae.
div.p: SAr≈øaparilla, is brought to us from the the Spani≈øh We≈øt-Indies, is more like long Weed than a Root; if good, very round, well fed, full, mealy, and white within, (if cut) the hungry, and lean, is nothing near ≈øo good. There is a wild Sar≈øaparilla which cometh from Jam ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ c ‚Ä¢ , which is large, but not mealy, rather woody and ≈øtalky; it is worth little to the former. They come in round Collars and long Bundles, and are (I mean the be≈øt in Collars) brought to us from Spain.

div.head: Radix Serpentariae Virg.
div.p:
VIrginy Snack Root, is a ≈ømall viperous Root, of a ≈øtrong, hot, aromatical ta≈øt, of a Par≈ønip colour: 'Tis
brought from Virginia; the goodne≈øs is known by the ≈ømell and cleanne≈øs, being free from Sand or Du≈øt.

div.head: Radix Sciilae.
div.p: SQuills, are a ≈øort of Sea Onions, of a large and great bigne≈øs: There are two ≈øorts, viz. red and white: Tho≈øe which are dry and ≈øound are to be preferred. They grow in Apulia, Portugal, ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ ily, and other places; from whence ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ey are brought to us.

div.head: Radix Scorzonerae.
div.p: SCorcionera Roots, are brought to us from Germany: Tho≈øe which are large, fre≈øh coloured, a yellowi≈øh red without, and white within, are be≈øt.

div.head: Radix Thap≈øiae.
div.p: THap≈øie Turpith, is much like unto white Dictamus Roots, &c. like the ≈ømalle≈øt Winter Bark, whiti≈øh; it is of ‚Ä¢ ittle u≈øe, and is brought from the Ea≈øt-Indies and the Straits.

div.head: Radix Tormentillae.
div.p: TOrmentill Roots grow here in England, Germany, France, and mo≈øt parts of Europe.

div.head: Radix Turpethi.
div.p: OF Turpith there are two ≈øorts; the be≈øt is that which is brought from Turky, called Turpethum Alexandrinum and Arabum, tho≈øe being places of its growth, it is large and gummy: That which comes from the Ea≈øt-Indies, is nothing near ≈øo good.

div.head: Radix Zedoariae.
div.p: TWO ≈øorts are likewi≈øe of Zedoaria, the long and the round, both being of a white colour, ≈øtrong ≈ømell and ta≈øt, ≈øomewhat near re≈øembling Ginger. It is brought from Turky, and like to grow in Synnea, and the further parts of the East-Indies.

div.head: Radix Zinziberis.
div.p: GInger, of this the white and black; the white is generally the be≈øt e≈øteemed; great Quantities come from Barbadoes and other parts of the We≈øt-Indies; and there is likewi≈øe a great deal in the Ea≈øt Indies, but mo≈øt which is brought from thence, is confited or green Ginger.

div.head: Re≈øina Pinca.
div.p: THe Ro≈øin of a Pine-tree, is like common Ro≈øin, of very little u≈øe.

div.head: Re≈øina Jalapii.
div.p: RO≈øin of Jallop is of a Chymical Preparation, the ≈øame being drawn from a good black ro≈øiny Jallop; its goodne≈øs is known by being clear, tran≈øparent in a manner.

div.head: Re≈øina Scammonii.
div.p: RO≈øin of Scamony is likewi≈øe drawn from Scamony, in a Chymical way, as the Ro≈øin of Jallop, afore≈øaid.

div.head: Sal Ab≈øinthii.
div.p: SALT of Wormwood is Chimically made of Wormwood, being calcined very dry and white is the be≈øt.

div.head: Sal Artemi≈øiae.
div.p: IS a Chimical Salt made of Mug ‚Ä¢ vort, by calcining, filtring, &c.

div.head: Sal Ammoniacum.
div.p: OF which there is two ≈øorts, the Potlid ≈øort, and the Sugar Loaf ≈øort; the be≈øt is clear and white; the former, which comes from Turkey, and the latter which comes from the Ea≈øt-Indies, is the wor≈øt ≈øort.

div.head: Sal Chalybis.
div.p: OR Salt of Steel, is a Chimical Preparation made here in England, &c.

div.head: Sal Cardui.
div.p: IS likewi≈øe Chimically made of the ble≈ø≈øed Thi≈øtle, by burning it to A≈øhes, calcining and filtring, and rendring it to a Salt, which has very little of the ta≈øte of Carduus.

div.head: Sal Cochleariae.
div.p: SAlt of Scurvey gra≈øs is Chimically made, as that of Wormwood, and therefore much like it.

div.p: IS likewi≈øe Chymically made, from the ≈øaid Herb, as the other Salt afore≈øaid.

div.p: ALias Sal Fo≈ø≈øile, is a Salt which is in ≈øtony pieces, like pieces of Cry≈øtal, almo≈øt tran≈øparent, breaking in four ≈øquare pieces; that which is clear and clean is the be≈øt. It comes from Dantzick, Italy and France.

div.head: Sal Geni≈øtae.
div.p: IS Chymically made from Broom, as Salt of Wormwood, &c. afore≈øaid.

div.head: Sal Nitrum.
div.p: SAlt Petre, is a ≈øulphureous Salt drawn out of the Earth; the be≈øt is that which will ea≈øily be ≈øet on Fire, and which is well refined, clear and tran≈øparant, in lumps and roches: The greate≈øt part comes from the Ea≈øt-India's; ≈øome little may be drawn out of Stables, Cellars, and other places.

div.head: Sal Prunellae, or Lapis Prunellae
div.p: IS nothing el≈øe but a refined Salt Peter, melted down and ca≈øt in Cakes, &c. in a Chymical way with Flos Sulphur.

div.head: Sal Succini.
div.p:
SAlt of Amber; is a volatile Salt which comes over in the drawing of the Oyl of Amber; the ≈øaid Salt playing up, and ≈øticking fa≈øt to the Neck of the Retort,
from whence it is taken and prepared 'tis of an Acid Ta≈øt, and if well refined will be whiti≈øh.

div.head: Sal Tartari.
div.p: SAlt of Tartar, is Chymically made of Argol, &c.

div.head: Sael Vitrioli.
div.p: SAlt of Vitriol is Chymically drawn from White Copperas, off the Caput Mortum of Vitriol.

div.head: Saccharum Saturni.
div.p: SUgar of Lead is made by a Chymical way from white Lead and Di≈øtilled Vinegar: The be≈øt is light whiti≈øh, in long Flakes:

div.head: Saccharum Cand Alb.
div.p: WHite Sugar Candy is made by the Sugar Bakers here in England, and mo≈øt parts of Europe; the cleane≈øt and whiti≈øt is to be prefered.

div.head: Sanguis Draconis.
div.p: DRagons Blood is brought from Bantam in the Ea≈øt-India's: 'Tis the Juice of a Tree, who≈øe Fruit is red like a Cherry; ≈øome of it is extraordinary fine, which comes in Drops wrapp'd up in Flags; others in round large Rowls, covered over with Flags; the cour≈øer is in Lumps: the goodne≈øs is known by its fine red Colour, when ≈øtruck upon white Paper.

div.head: Sanguis Hirci.
div.p: IS the Blood of a Young Goat, dryed up, &c.

div.head: Scinci Marini.
div.p: ARe Creatures with four Legs, a Head and a Tail, like an Eft; they ≈øwim in Ponds, and feed upon odoriferous Herbs. They are ≈øent over dryed up and ≈øalted; tho≈øe which are large, not broken, dry and fre≈øh Coloured are the be≈øt. They come from Venice.

div.head: Scorpiones Terre≈øtres.
div.p: SCorpions are a kind of a Venomous Worm or In≈øect, much re≈øembling a Cray-Fi≈øh, with his Tail having a ≈øharp Sting bended like a Claw. They are ≈øometimes brought over alive from Germany, otherwi≈øe they are dryed. The large≈øt are be≈øt, but the live ones are reckoned far better.

div.head: Serieum Crudum.
div.p: IS the Bag, or the ≈øilken Pouches of the Silk-worm, which the Silk-worm ≈øpins the Silk upon. They are to be had in all places from whence Silk u≈øes to come; being about the bigne≈øs of a Birds Egg, and ≈øome bigger.

div.head: Sevum Cervinum.
div.p: STags, or Deers Tallow, is made in Enggland, and all parts of Europe; being very hard and white, of a ≈øweet ≈ømell if fre≈øh.

div.head: Courteous Reader.
div.p: THE Intent of this Book was chiefly to know the place of Growth of mo≈øt Drugs, being thereto de≈øired by an intire Friend of mine. The De≈øcription, and of the quality of every Drug is difficult enough, but would be more in the Seeds; which cannot well be ≈øhown but by Eye-≈øight: Therefore I have only to all tho≈øe ≈øeveral Seeds, which come from beyond the Sea, ≈øet the places from whence they are brought.

div.head: * Scammonium.
div.p: IS the Juice of the Roots of Scamony, which is full of a Milky Juice, which is thickned and made up in old Boots. The be≈øt of it comes from Aleppo, being clean, free from Sand and Dro≈øs, ≈øhining like Ro≈øin, breaking ea≈øily, and if touch'd with the Tongue, turning white like Milk.
The Scamony which comes from Smyrna, is generally not ≈øo fine as the Aleppo, being heavy, more dro≈ø≈øie, and ≈øometimes full of Du≈øt and Sand.

div.head: Sperma Coeti.
div.p: IS ≈øaid to be the Seed of a Whale: There has been Sperma Coeti Whales caught upon the Coa≈øt of Ireland, but more commonly 'tis found in a dead Whales Head near Bermoodos. The Sperma Coeti, is to be cho≈øen very white, as Snow, in large and great Flakes, not oyly, or di≈øcoloured, nor of a ≈øtrong ≈ømell.

div.head: Spiritus Salis Ammon.
div.p: SPirit Sal-Ammoniack, is Chymically drawn from the Sal Ammoniack, &c. which being very clear, like Rock Water; but of a mo≈øt ≈øtrong volatil Spirit, enough to ≈øtrike any Man's breath in ≈ømelling to a Quantity.

div.head: Spiritus ≈øalis Com.
div.p: SPirit of Salt is likewi≈øe Chymically drawn from Bay Salt, of an Acid ta≈øt: The be≈øt is heavy, and of an Amber colour.

div.head: Spiritus Mellis.
div.p: THE Spirit of Honey is Chymically drawn from Honey, by Retort.

div.head: Spiritus Vitrioli.
div.p: IS likewi≈øe Chymically drawn from Copperas, &c.

div.head: Spiritus Cornu Cervi.
div.p: IS drawn from Harts-horn: The Oyl being ≈øeparated, and the ≈øpirit rectified, is as clear as Cry≈øtal.

div.head: Spiritus Cochleariae.
div.p: IS al≈øo Chymically drawn from Scurvy-Gra≈øs, and Spirit of Wine; ta≈øting very ≈øtrong of the Scrvy-Gra≈øs; and as clear as Water.

div.head: Spiritus Ab≈øinthii.
div.p: IS drawn Chymically from Wormwood, &c.

div.head: Spiritus Sulphuris.
div.p: IS likewi≈øe drawn from Brim≈øtone, by Retort.

div.head: Spica Nardi Indicae.
div.p:
IS a kind of a Root which comes from the Ea≈øt-Indies; of a fragrant, ≈øtrong ≈ømell, and as it were hairy: That which is light, long, and ≈øhort haired, is to be
cho≈øen; of a yellow colour, inclining to a red, of a bitter ta≈øt, ≈øticking to the Tongue.

div.head: * Spica Nardi Celticae.
div.p: CEltick Spicknard, is a kind of Flowers made up in bundles; the leaves of a bright yellow, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling Marigold-flowers, of a ≈øtrong fragrant ≈ømell, being free from Sand and Du≈øt, and full of ≈ømall Roots.

div.head: Spongia.
div.p: SPunges grow under Water, at the ≈øide of Rocks; The greate≈øt part are brought to us from Smyrna and Aleppo, and other plaees in Turkey. Tho≈øe which are fine feel ≈ømooth and clo≈øe, not too full of large Holes: They are ≈øaid to grow mo≈øt in the Archipelago. Tho≈øe which are large, fine, clo≈øe and lively coloured, either white or yellow, are to be preferred.

div.head: Sebe≈øten.
div.p:
IS a Fruit of a Tree much like unto a ≈ømall Prune, the ≈øtone within almo≈øt
four-≈øquare, of a black colour; they are to be cho≈øen: Tho≈øe which are fre≈øh, plump, full of Meat, and moi≈øt; they are imported from Italy. They grow likewi≈øe in Syria and Egypt.

div.head: Styrax Liquida.
div.p: LIquid Styrax, is a fat liquor, as thick as many Bal≈øam; of a ≈øtrong and fragrant ≈ømell, if clear and good, of a whiti≈øh colour: 'Tis kept in Water becau≈øe of its clammine≈øs. The ≈øame comes from the Straits.

div.head: Succus Acacia.
div.p: IS the Juice of a Thorny Fruit called Acacia, growing in Egypt; out of its Seeds the true Acacia is made by Expre≈ø≈øion; the colour not ≈øo black, but more inclining to a red, which above all other, is to be preferred in making of Venice Treacle. The Acacia now in u≈øe, is made of Sloes in Germany, and brought over in round Balls, wrapp'd up in Bladders. The goodne≈øs is known by its ≈øharp Re≈øtringency.

div.head: Succus Liquiritiae Angl.
div.p: ENgli≈øh Juice of Liquori≈øh, is made in round Balls and ≈øealed; it is generally made up with old Prunes, Liquori≈øh, and ≈øuch other Trumperies, and therefore far inferiour to the Spani≈øh Juice.

div.head: Succus Glycyrrhizae Hi≈øp.
div.p: SPani≈øh Juice of Liquori≈øh, is made by boyling the Juice to a Conden≈øity, to make it up in Rolls and Cakes, wrapt up in Bay-leaves: The be≈øt breaks freely and clear, ≈øhining like Jet, free from being burnt to. 'Tis brought out of Italy.

div.head: Succus Hypoci≈øtis.
div.p: IS the Juice of a Plant, being pre≈ø≈øed out when in its Flowers, and dried up in the Sun, and not unlike to Juice of Liquori≈øh; being brought from Italy and Germany.

div.head: Succus Kermes.
div.p:
JUice of Alkermes, is made of Alkermes Berries, &c. and brought over from

div.head: Sulphur Vivum.
div.p: OR live Brim≈øtone, is nothing el≈øe but Brim≈øtone, before Fu≈øion, of a grayi≈øh colour, and acid ta≈øt; and not ≈øo ea≈øie to take fire, as other Brim≈øtone, It is brought to us from Italy.

div.head: Talcum Com.
div.p: COmmon Tale looks red without, and white within: There is a great deal to be had in Germany, and in York≈øhire, here in England.

div.head: Talcum Venetum.
div.p:
VEnetian Talk, is a Stone which ≈øhines, of ≈øeveral colours, as it were of Gold, Silver and green; and therefore by ≈øome called the Star of the Earth; yet it will

div.head: * Tamarindi.
div.p: IS the Fruit of a ≈ømall Shrub in the Ea≈øt-Indies, growing like A≈øh-keys. The be≈øt is reckoned to be the red, of a lively, ≈øharp, accid ta≈øt; others like the black ≈øort better; tho≈øe which are lea≈øt ≈øtony and ≈øtringy, are to be preferred: They come from the Ea≈øt-Indies.

div.head: Tartarum Album.
div.p: WHite Argol, or Rheni≈øh Argol, the be≈øt is that which comes from Heylbron and Strasbourg breaking clear, and free, without Dro≈øs: It is brought out of Germany.

div.head: Tartarum Rubruns.
div.p: REd Argol is very cour≈øe: 'Tis brought to us from Genoua, Florence, and ≈øome parts of France.

div.p: IS a Chymical Preparation made out of Oyl of Tartar, per Deliquium, and Oyl of Vitriol.

div.head: * Tea.
div.p: IS a ≈ømall Herb of a Shrub which grows in China; the ≈øame is u≈øed in mo≈øt Coffee-Hou≈øes: The goodne≈øs con≈øi≈øts of a fine green Tenderne≈øs, excellent fragrant ≈ømell, like Violet, and to keep a good, clear, and green colour in the Water; being chewed, ≈øtreaks very green like Gra≈øs; of it are ≈øeveral ≈øorts which mu≈øt be di≈øtingui≈øhed by the Eye, ta≈øt and ≈ømell, above all the leaves, fine, cri≈øp'd, green, inclining to Razor-blew-colour.

div.head: Terra Sigillata Alb.
div.p: IS a thing made out of fine Earth, and ≈øealed here in England.

div.head: Terra Sigi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a Rubr.
div.p:
IS likewi≈øe made here, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ led; their goodne≈øs are according to what Earth

div.head: Terra Lemnia.
div.p: IS a fatti≈øh red Earth, coming from Turky, by ≈øome called Axungia Solis, this is a fatter Earth, and darker red, than the fine Bole; the goodne≈øs of it con≈øi≈øts, if thrown into Water, to ri≈øe up in Bubbles, if touched by the Tongue, to adhere to it.

div.head: Terra Sigillata V ‚Ä¢ ra.
div.p: USED to be brought out of Turky, ≈øealed with Turki≈øh Characters; but of late ≈øeveral Fallacies being di≈øcovered, there is a Sealed Earth made out of Terra Lemnia; and ≈øome ≈øealed Earths are brought from Germany, growing near Strigonia, which is by modern Phy≈øicians be≈øt e≈øteemed.

div.head: * Terra Japonica, alias Catechu.
div.p: IS a dark colour'd Earth, like to cour≈øe Aloes Socatrina; if chewed, it di≈ø≈øolves, ta≈øtes ad≈øtringent in the Mouth, and ≈øweet in the Throat: 'Tis brought from the Ea≈øt-Indies.

div.head: Terra Samia.
div.p: IS an Earth which comes from Armenia, growing near a City called Samos: 'Tis ad≈øtringent, and of a yellowi≈øh colour.

div.p: IS brought to us in great Abundance from France, from whence the Oyl of Turpentine is drawn in Quantities, and little Barrels of ≈øeveral Weights, are made up for the Druggi≈øts u≈øe: 'Tis of a thick Body, ≈øtrong ≈ømell, and whiti≈øh colour.

div.p: VEnetian Turpentine, is of a thin, clear, tran≈øparent Body, and indifferently well ≈øcented: 'Tis brought from thence, and ≈øome parts of Germany, as Brechmen, being brought down from Salzburgh and N ‚Ä¢ rimburgh, &c.

div.p:
IS of a green, and inclining to an Amber colour; very clear, well ≈øcented,

div.p: IS brought to us in Gourds; ≈øomething re≈øembling Chio Turpentine, but that it is generally foul, and full of Dro≈øs, and a thicker body than any other.

div.head: * Terebinthina √® Chio.
div.p: CHio Turpentine, comes over from Turkey in earthen Pots, is very clear and thick, of a yellowi≈øh colour.

div.head: Tincal.
div.p: IS nothing el≈øe but an unrefined Borax, brought over to us in Tuppers, from the Ea≈øt-Indies: The be≈øt, is that which is in large greeni≈øh pieces, free from Mud, (which it is generally pe≈øtered with) as al≈øo, ≈ømall Pibble ≈øtones) and grea≈øed over with ≈øtinking Oyl, which is ≈øaid to be Neats-foot Oyl. The drie≈øt, cleane≈øt, and large≈øt is therefore to be preferred.

div.head: Trochi≈øci de Viperis,
div.p: 'TIs a little round Cake, made and ≈øealed, with the Mucilage of the Powder of Vipers, and beaten Biskets, and dryed in the Sun. The be≈øt come from Venice.

div.head: Turne≈øole.
div.p: ARE nothing but old Rags, and Linnon dipped in the red juice of Grapes, (others ≈øay in Mulberry juice) and dried up in the Sun: They ≈øtrike a red colour in White-Wine, or other Water, like Claret. They come to us out of France.

div.head: THUS.
div.p: FRankincen≈øe, is brought to us from France, in large pieces; that which is be≈øt, is in large, dry and white pieces.

div.head: Vi≈øcus Quercinus.
div.p: THE be≈øt of Mi≈ø≈øeltoes; are found upon large Oaks, almo≈øt the colour of the ≈øame; other Mi≈ø≈øels are found upon Apple Trees, and others; but not ≈øo good.

div.head: Vi≈øcus Aucupum.
div.p: OR Bird-Lime, is a thing made here in England, with which Nut-Oyl being ≈øtruck over little Rods, is ≈øo clammy, that it fa≈øteneth the ≈ømall Birds to it.

div.head: Vitriolum Album.
div.p: VVHite Cop ‚Ä¢ eras comes to us from Hamborow; that in large and great Pigs, white, and not yellow nor du≈øty, is looked upon the be≈øt.

div.head: Vi ‚Ä¢ riolum Viride.
div.p: GReen Copperas is made in great quantities here in England, from a round Stone which is found in the I≈øle of Wight, and old-ru≈øty Iron.

div.head: Vitriolum Dantz.
div.p: IS made in Pru≈ø≈øia; the ≈øame running more upon Copper: This is looked upon better than Engli≈øh.

div.head: Vitriolum Hungariae.
div.p: THE Hungarian Vitriol, is of a blewi≈øh green colour: 'Tis ≈øaid to grow near Silver, Gold and Copper: Several Counterfeits are ≈øold for it.

div.head: Vitriolum Roman.
div.p: ROman Vitriol, is vulgarly ≈øo called, it is nothing el≈øe but Cypre≈øs Vitrio, in cut Stones, very blew like a Sapphire. There is another ≈øort which comes in Duppers from the Ea≈øt Indies, not inferiour to the former, but that it generally runs together in lumps, and not loo≈øe, nor in cut Stones.

div.head: Ungula Alcis.
div.p: ELks claws, come to us from Dantzick. The be≈øt are tho≈øe which are large, full Legs to the upper Knuckle, full Hooff'd, and well Haired.

div.p: ORange Flower Butter is made from the Orange Flower, and if right, with Pomatum. The be≈øt comes from Bermoodos; ≈øome good comes from France and Genoua.

div.head: U≈ønea Cranii Humani.
div.p: THE Mo≈øs of a Scull of any dead ‚Ä¢ ody dying violently, and left unburied in the Field, we have ≈øeen it in ≈øome Sculls brought from Ireland.

div.head: Zibethum, or Civet.
div.p:
THE be≈øt of it is reckoned to be made in England, though a great deal more
is made in Holland, and with Certificates Tran≈øported into mo≈øt parts of Europe. That which is clear, of a fine, lively, whiti≈øh colour, not mixt with Butter, &c. is to be preferred. The African, Barbados, and other Civets coming from the We≈øt-Indies, are next to it: But that blacki≈øh ≈øort which comes from the Ea≈øt-Indies, is by none which under≈øtands any, looked upon as any thing.

div.head: Zinziber Condit.
div.p: GReen Ginger is brought from ≈øeveral parts into England, as from the Ea≈øt-Indies, We≈øt-Indies, and of late, a great deal from Barbados. That which is clear, large, not ≈øtringy, is the be≈øt.

div.head: Zylobal≈øamum.
div.p: SEE Lignum Lenti≈øcinum, being the ≈øame.
